We found that η' is mainly composed of strange quark pairs (ss) at low energies, but as the energy increases, its composition becomes increasingly non-strange.

This result supports our previous findings based on the analysis of the decay widths of these mesons into π mesons and K mesons.

We propose an efficient computational method to calculate the elastic properties, vibrational frequencies, and normal modes of proteins through finite element analysis (FEA).
The proposed method is based on representing each amino acid residue as a node and constructing a 3D tetrahedral mesh that covers the entire target structure.
We demonstrate how to effectively calculate the stiffness matrix associated with the system under study using this representation in finite element analysis (FEA).

In addition, we demonstrate how to obtain accurate results for the system's characteristic frequencies and corresponding modal shapes by solving the generalized eigenvalue problem that arises from the discrete form of the governing equations using the same formulation.
Finally, we illustrate our method through several numerical examples involving different types of proteins.

Our results indicate that the proposed method provides high-precision predictions in terms of accuracy compared to other state-of-the-art methods, such as molecular dynamics simulations or coarse-grained models.

The smallness of the observed vacuum energy density is one of the most perplexing problems in present-day physics, and some have suggested addressing this issue by considering the effects of quantum gravity on vacuum fluctuations.

We present the results of an unbiased survey of compact HII regions in the southern Galactic plane using data obtained from the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA).

We used data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) to measure the cosmic flow field in the local universe for the first time.
The flow field is defined as the irrotational component of a special velocity field, which can be used to measure the net effect of tidal forces on galaxy clusters.

We used a sample containing 13,000 galaxy clusters, with spectral redshifts in the range of 0.01 < z < 0.1. The selection was made by applying an adaptive halo mass cut to the SDSS maxBCG cluster catalog.

Finally, we demonstrate how to use our results to test the consistency of cosmological models with observational data.

The problem of formula evaluation for conjunctive normal form (CNF) propositional logic formulas has been extensively studied, and many efficient algorithms have been developed.
However, most existing methods are not suitable for evaluating large conjunctive normal forms (CNFs) that have millions or even billions of clauses due to their high computational complexity.

In this work, we propose two novel techniques that significantly improve the efficiency of CNF formula evaluators: one based on GPU-based parallelization, and the other achieved through representing each clause as a bit vector instead of a set of literals for data compression.

We implemented these techniques in the new software package CLEVER-CNF, which outperformed state-of-the-art solvers such as SATzilla and Lingeling when evaluated against multiple benchmark sets, including those used in the recent SAT competition.

The human brain can change throughout life by forming new connections between neurons or eliminating existing connections.
This ability enables humans to adapt to their environment and continuously learn.

Neural prosthetics are electronic systems designed to interface directly with the nervous system, used to restore functions lost due to injury or disease.

We propose an algorithm for synthesizing phase screens that is optimal in the sense of minimizing the mean square error between the synthesized phase and the desired phase, while being constrained by the maximum number of degrees of freedom (DOF) available for synthesis.

The method is based on representing each screen as a linear combination of basis functions, which are obtained by applying the Karhunen-Loeve transformation to a set of reference phase screens generated using standard methods, such as those described by Kolmogorov or von Kármán statistics.

We demonstrate how to use this representation to generate new phase screens, whose statistical properties closely match those of the original reference screen, while satisfying the constraints of the total degrees of freedom (DOF) required for all N screens in the user-specified representation sequence.
This method was implemented in the context of the SPARTA software package developed at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.
In addition, we describe several techniques that have been incorporated into our implementation to improve computational efficiency when generating a large number of phase screens.

We analyzed the concept of algorithm reducibility in computational complexity theory, focusing on its role as a bridge between different areas within the field.

We believe that there are at least two different ways to understand how one problem can be reduced to another through algorithms; this roughly corresponds to the concepts of polynomial-time reduction and Turing reduction.
The former is more commonly used than the latter, but we demonstrate how to understand both in relation to the concept of relativizing polynomial time.

Specifically, we demonstrate that every problem that is not NP-complete under Turing reductions must possess a certain property, which makes it relatively easy to solve with respect to any oracle set that contains all NP sets.
This result has implications for the relationship between P and NP, and also provides new insights into the structure of NP itself.

Algorithmic reductions play a central role in computational complexity theory, providing a way to relate seemingly unrelated categories of decision problems, such as those belonging to NP (nondeterministic polynomial time computable problems) and those belonging to co-NP (the complement of NP problems).

However, despite their importance, there has been relatively little focus on the exact meaning of the phrase "algorithmically reducible"; in fact, fundamental questions about this concept remain unanswered.

We present the results of an optical spectral survey aimed at searching for tidal dwarf galaxy (TDG) candidates from a sample of ultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs).

We obtained spectra using the VLT's FORS2 and Gemini's GMOS-N telescopes, covering a wavelength range from 3600 Å to 9200 Å. A total of 16 ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs) were selected based on their high far-infrared luminosity (L FIR > 10^12 L ⊙) and low redshift (z < 0.1).
The main goal is to search for tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) that are expected to appear around interacting systems, such as ultra-luminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs).
The presence of young stars among these objects may allow them to be detected through strong emission lines such as Hα or [OII].
However, we did not detect any significant emission line flux beyond what can be explained by the star formation occurring within the host galaxy.

This result indicates that either our sample of ultra-bright infrared galaxies does not have accompanying tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs), or they are too faint and/or too red to be detected by current observational facilities.

We study the effect of noise on spatially extended systems by extending the concept of non-equilibrium potential (NEP).

We indicate that NEP can be used to characterize different types of stochastic resonance, such as the resonance observed in excitable systems and bistable systems near their respective Hopf bifurcations.
In particular, we found that the presence of noise enhanced the amplitude of vibrations in both cases, but the mechanisms were very different.

The multifractal characteristics of human heartbeat have been studied by many authors, but most research has focused on short time series (usually less than one hour).

From this work, we studied the scaling properties of long-term electrocardiogram (ECG) recordings during sleep in healthy subjects, using wavelet transform to calculate the singularity spectrum f(α), which characterizes the multifractal degree present in each signal.
We found that all signals exhibit a wide range of exponent α, indicating a strong multifractality.
The width of these spectra Δα decreases as the recording time T increases, and when T ≥ 10 hours, Δα ~ T^(-1/2).
This indicates that when considering longer time records, the electrocardiogram becomes more characterized by a single fractal feature.
Finally, we demonstrate how our results can be used to detect pathological changes in heart rate variability associated with congestive heart failure.

The aim of this study is to investigate the effects of a novel antimicrobial cyclic peptide (referred to as microbe-derived cationic ring structures, MCRs) on cell proliferation and apoptosis induction in A549 non-small cell lung cancer cells.
The results showed that the treatment with MCR1 or MCR3 significantly inhibited cell growth and induced G0/G1 phase arrest and cell apoptosis by activating the caspase-3/7/9 signaling pathway.
Additionally, we found that both MCR1 and MCR3 inhibited the expression levels of cyclin D1 and E, as well as CDK4/6 proteins, while increasing the level of p21WAF1/cip1.
In addition, our data indicate that MCR1 and MRC3 prevent the interaction between the insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R) and the retinoblastoma tumor suppressor protein (RB).
These findings suggest that MCR1 and MCR3 may be potential therapeutic drugs for the treatment of lung cancer.
We propose that the dark matter in the universe is composed of microcharged particles that are neutral under electromagnetic interactions but carry a charge of approximately 10^(-6)e (electron).
We demonstrate how to realize this scenario by introducing a new gauge boson with a mass of approximately mX ~ 1 TeV/c² into the Standard Model using the Stueckelberg extension.
Introducing such massive vector particles would lead to modifications to the conventional Feynman rules for charged fermions interacting via photons or gluons.

Specifically, we found that the scattering cross section between two microcharge particles mediated by photons is suppressed compared to the case where there are no additional heavy vector bosons present.

This suppression leads to a decrease in the number density of microcharged dark matter particles in the later stages, because their annihilation rate is slower than that of their massless counterparts.

We present the evolutionary results of primordial star accretion discs with magnetic fields, in which we include Ohmic diffusion and bidirectional diffusion, and consider radiation transfer effects using flux-limited diffusion (FLD).
We found that incorporating these additional physical processes has a significant impact on the structure and evolution of the disk.
In particular, we demonstrate that the presence of an initial magnetic field can significantly affect the mass distribution within the early disk by suppressing fragmentation near the central star.
This has led to the formation of larger disks than those previously discovered only through hydrodynamic simulations.
The generated disc becomes less expansive due to the increased pressure support provided by the magnetic field.
As time goes by, the magnetic field gradually dissipates through ohmic dissipation and turbulence driven by gravitational instability.
Once this happens, the disk becomes thinner and more expanded relative to the non-magnetic model.

Introduction: Local Decodable Codes (LCDs) are a type of error-correcting code, where each codeword has an associated decoding algorithm that can efficiently recover a single bit or symbol when queried.
Specifically, if the codeword is corrupted by up to t errors, there exists a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm that can recover the original undamaged word using O(t) queries per symbol.
This characteristic makes these encodings very useful in applications such as data storage systems, peer-to-peer networks, and streaming distribution services.
A large amount of research has focused on understanding the trade-offs between the rate of code, its distance, and the query complexity of the decoder.
For example, Guruswami et al. (2005), Chan et al. (2006), and Kopparty and Saraf (2007) studied coding problems that construct low query complexity while maintaining high rate and high distance.
Recently, some research has focused on improving the lower bounds on the minimum query complexity required to decode a single bit under certain levels of damage.

These include the recent groundbreaking results by Dvir et al. (2010a), which improved upon the previously known best upper bound proposed by Sudan et al. (2005), as well as the subsequent improvements made by Dvir et al. (2011), Feldman et al. (2012), and Kopparty et al. (2013).

Introduction: Many physical phenomena, such as magnetism or phase transitions, occur due to the collective behavior of many interacting particles.
For example, magnetic ordering in solids occurs due to the strong interactions of individual atoms through their magnetic moments.
Similarly, liquid helium exhibits superfluidity below its critical temperature \( T_c = 2.17 \, \text{K} \), as helium-4 atoms pair up to form tightly bound bosons known as Cooper pairs.
These examples indicate that understanding collective behavior requires studying large groups of interacting particles, rather than isolated individual particles.
However, simulating the macroscopic properties of complex systems composed of many interacting elements remains one of the most challenging problems in computational physics today.

Indeed, although the microscopic interactions between individual particles can usually be accurately described by quantum mechanics, describing the macroscopic properties of a large number of particles typically involves some approximations that cannot capture the subtle effects arising from correlations between different parts of the system.
Therefore, approximate methods, such as Monte Carlo sampling [1], are commonly used to perform numerical simulations of large-scale models of actual systems.
Unfortunately, when these methods are used to simulate systems that contain millions of elements, they become computationally very expensive.

1 Introduction  
In recent years, significant progress has been made in understanding the physical processes occurring near supermassive black holes (SMBH) in active galactic nuclei (AGN), quasars, and other similar systems.
These studies are based on observations of the broad band spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) spanning multiple decades in frequency space.
However, due to the vast distance between them, it is impossible to directly measure the intrinsic luminosity of most active galactic nuclei.
On the contrary, indirect methods, such as reverberation mapping or the statistical correlation between various active galactic nucleus (AGN) properties, can be used to determine their luminosity.
For example, if we know how much light passes through a certain region of interest in an active galactic nucleus (AGN), we can use simple geometric reasoning to calculate its luminosity.
Additionally, if the distance to an active galactic nucleus (AGN) is known, its absolute magnitude can be measured directly.
Unfortunately, both methods require a detailed understanding of the structure of the launch area, and currently, this information cannot be obtained through observation.

Therefore, to accurately estimate the luminosity of distant active galactic nuclei (AGNs), it is necessary to develop models that can reproduce the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) observed in nearby active galactic nuclei.
We proposed a method for extracting potential physical laws from a large amount of experimental data using machine learning techniques and statistical analysis.

The method is applied to two different examples: the measurement of electrical conductivity in doped semiconductors and the determination of the superconducting critical temperature Tc in copper oxychlorides.
In both of these cases, we check whether our results are consistent with theoretical predictions.
We demonstrate how this new technology can be used to identify unknown parameters, including those new phenomena that cannot be theoretically predicted at all.

One of the core objectives of modern science is to understand complex systems, such as materials or organisms, through their fundamental building blocks.
In order to achieve this goal, it is necessary to develop methods that can efficiently analyze a large amount of experimental data.
Here, we propose a novel approach that combines machine learning algorithms with advanced statistical tools.
Our method is illustrated in two examples: first, we study the dependence of conductivity on doping concentration in semiconductor compounds.
Secondly, we determine the critical temperature \( T_c \) for superconductivity in high-temperature copper oxides.
For these two questions, the results we obtained are very consistent with existing theories.
In addition, we demonstrate how our method enables people to discover previously unanticipated features in the data.

Detecting and characterizing planets that orbit other stars (i.e., non-solar stars) is one of the most exciting fields in modern astronomy and has significant implications for our understanding of planet formation and evolution.
Most known exoplanet systems have been found around single main-sequence stars (MS); however, it has been suggested that there may be more planets in binary star systems.

Finally, we summarize the current research results on planetary companions in binary systems involving main sequence stars and main sequence stars (MS+MS), main sequence stars and white dwarfs (MS+WD), white dwarfs and main sequence stars (WD+MS), as well as white dwarfs and white dwarfs (WD+WD).
Keywords: planetary systems; binary stars; exoplanets; direct imaging; astrometry.

We report the detection of an infrared dark cloud (IRDC) near the open cluster NGC 6334, with data obtained using the Infrared Array Camera (IRAC) on the Spitzer Space Telescope.
IRDC is associated with the molecular cloud complex G327.3+0.6 and was identified as Bok globule CB190 by Clemens and Barvainis (1988).
We found that this object exhibits a distinct 24-micron shadow, which may be caused by its absorption of bright mid-infrared radiation from a nearby protostar or young stellar object.
This feature indicates that the cloud contains a dense core at different evolutionary stages.
Using near-infrared extinction mapping, we identified two candidate starless cores within the cloud.
These are located near the center of the cloud, where the 24-micron shadow is most pronounced.
Our analysis indicates that these core masses range from 0.5 solar masses to 1 solar mass, with radii ranging from 1000 astronomical units to 3000 astronomical units.
We present new results based on infrared photometric data obtained from ISO-SWS, IRAS, MSX, and Spitzer-IRS, studying the mass loss of carbon-rich asymptotic giant branch (AGB) stars.
We found no correlation between the total luminosity or effective temperature of these celestial bodies and their mass loss rate.
The observed dispersion may be explained by differences in chemical composition and/or pulsation characteristics among individual sources.
In addition, we demonstrated that the ratio of dust to gas decreases at higher temperatures in oxygen-rich and carbon-rich red giants.
This indicates that the physical conditions for dust formation in the two types of evolved stars are different.
Finally, we discussed how to apply our findings to improve the current models that describe the evolution of red giants.
Keywords: Asymptotic Giant Branch Stars; Dust Formation; Red Giants; Mass Loss.

1 Introduction 

Carbon-rich asymptotic giant branch (AGB; hereafter referred to as Crich AGB) stars have been extensively studied over the past few decades because they represent an important source of interstellar material.
They lose a large amount of material through interstellar wind caused by radiation pressure acting on dust particles formed in the ejected gas.

These winds play a crucial role in the formation and evolution of the interstellar envelopes around stars, thus affecting the appearance of planetary nebulae and the protostellar disks surrounding young stellar objects.
However, despite numerous observational studies, it remains unclear what factors determine the amount of mass lost by Crich AGB stars.

We indicate that, in addition to gravitational waves and neutrinos, there is an additional source of energy loss in the final stages of stellar evolution that has largely been overlooked in previous studies.

This happened because around a redshift z of about 1100, the universe became transparent to photons (this is the moment when matter and radiation reached equilibrium), allowing them to freely flow out into space.
The reduction of pressure has caused the expansion rate of the universe to be faster than before, thereby accelerating its rate of expansion.
We estimate this effect for different types of stars and find that it could be significant—due to this process, up to 10% of the total luminosity output of giants may be lost.
Specifically, we predict that if this effect is not corrected, the peak brightness of Type Ia supernovae should systematically be lower than their observed values.
Finally, we discussed how to use the current data on distant supernovae to perform observational tests of our results.

We study the relationship between network structure, dynamics, and function, using a complex and experimentally accessible example system—the neuronal circuit of the brain.
We demonstrate how to use statistical mechanics methods to analyze the functional characteristics of the system as it evolves over time through its fundamental structural connectivity.
Specifically, we focus on the role played by switches, which are nodes of high centrality; their removal would cause a large portion of the network to become disconnected.
Our results indicate that these switches play an important role in maintaining overall dynamic stability while allowing for local flexibility.
The manuscript is divided into four parts.
The first part introduces our model and describes some basic features of the generation network.
The second part presents numerical simulations that illustrate how switching affects the evolution of the system.
The third part analyzes the effect of removing switches on the network's ability to maintain synchronization under disturbances.
Finally, the fourth part discusses the possible expansions of our work.

The main objective of this paper is to attempt to use recursion as an alternative method for querying databases, using Prolog (a declarative language) and SQL (Structured Query Language).
The first part introduces the structure of the current database and some background on queries; it also introduces the concept of recursion and its applications in computer science.
In the second part, we demonstrated experiments using recursion in Prolog, showing that recursion can be used to express complex queries without relying on program code or other languages like Java.
Finally, in the third part, we discuss the results obtained by applying recursion in SQL systems.
We conclude that despite many attempts to implement recursion in SQL systems, there has not been a single success so far due to the inherent technical challenges of these systems.

We studied the properties of strong peak points in Banach spaces, defined as follows.
Let X be a normed space over the real or complex numbers, with a dual space X*.

We present the results of our analysis of the supersymmetry parameter space, taking into account all available experimental data, including data from the LHC experiments and electroweak precision observables (EWPO).
We found that when we correctly take into account the complete correlation of EWPO, there is no significant improvement compared to the previous analysis.

We present the results of N-body simulations aimed at studying tidal disruption and material accumulation in interacting galaxy pairs, with a particular emphasis on the formation of tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs).

We proposed an algorithm for finding the optimal matching between two clustering sets, which we call "true clustering."
A true cluster is defined as a group of points in a high-dimensional space that are close to each other and far away from all other points in that space.

Introduction  
The issue being discussed here is the data association problem—given two sets of observations (for example, images), determine which pairs correspond to the same physical object.

This problem often occurs when dealing with multiple object views, such as the view shown in Figure 1. Due to calibration errors, occlusions, and other reasons, perfect registration between the two images may not always be achievable.

In many applications, there is some prior knowledge about the correspondence between two sets of observations; for example, if they are taken with the same sensor but at different times, their relative pose will be known, constrained only by a scale factor.
In these situations, the goal becomes to use this information to improve the accuracy of the final solution.
Our method relies on the concept of "true clustering":
A real cluster is a group of points in high-dimensional space that are close to each other while being relatively far from other points in the space.
For example, consider the case of registering two images that depict a scene with several people standing side by side.
Everyone forms their own real group because his/her appearance does not undergo significant changes over time.
On the other hand, the background is changing dramatically, so there is no single cluster that can correspond to the entire background area.
Given two sets of true clusters corresponding to the first and second observations, we want to find the best assignment between them.
To this end, we define a cost function based on the distances between each pair of points within the true clusters.
Then, we formulate the problem as a quadratic integer programming problem and efficiently solve it using the branch-and-bound technique.

Introduction  
Galaxies are complex systems whose properties strongly depend on their mass, age, chemical composition, star formation history, and environment.
These physical characteristics determine many observable quantities, such as brightness, color, shape, and dynamics, which have been extensively studied over the decades.

However, recently there has been a significant degeneracy among some observable quantities, making them unable to be uniquely determined without additional information about the underlying physics or geometry of the system.

For example, the total brightness of a galaxy depends not only on its current star formation rate but also on its past star formation activity, which is reflected in the integrated light of older stars.
Similarly, the color of the galaxy depends not only on its metallicity but also on the amount of dust extinction along our line of sight.
Therefore, accurate measurement of all relevant physical parameters requires detailed spectral observations that cover a wide range of wavelengths.

Such research has become possible today due to new space missions, including GALEX, SDSS, 2MASS, the Spitzer Space Telescope, the Herschel Space Observatory, the Chandra X-ray Observatory, XMM-Newton, the Hubble Space Telescope, and most importantly, the upcoming launch of the European Space Agency's Gaia satellite.
Gaia is expected to provide astrometric positions, parallaxes, proper motions, radial velocities, and multi-color photometric measurements for over one billion celestial bodies.

These proofs are quantum protocols that allow one party (referred to as Alice) to convince another party (referred to as Bob) that she knows certain secret information while keeping her secret hidden.

More formally, let us consider an interaction protocol between Alice and Bob that consists of two stages: the first stage comprises a series of rounds in which Alice sends qubits to Bob, and Bob measures them according to the measurement basis he has chosen.
At the end of each round, Bob will publicly announce whether he accepts or rejects the status he has received.
If Bob accepts at least half of the statuses sent by Alice, then the second phase begins; otherwise, the protocol ends after the current round.
In the second stage, Alice revealed her secret to Bob, as he had reached a sufficient status in the previous stage.
Otherwise, all parties will suspend the agreement.

We proposed an analytical model for high-order harmonic generation (HHG) in diatomic molecules, based on the concept of molecular orbitals and their associated electronic wave functions.
The HHG process can be understood as a sequence of three steps: first, electrons are ionized under the influence of a strong laser field.
Secondly, they propagate along the continuum until they undergo scattering with the parent ion.
Thirdly, the returning electrons will emit high-order harmonics when they interact again with the driving field.

We demonstrate that this viewpoint leads to a simple expression for describing the harmonic intensity of the emission, which depends only on two parameters that characterize the molecular orbital structure.

This result allows us to explain the observed interference patterns of different harmonics through the constructive or destructive interference between the contributions of different molecular orbitals.
In addition, we demonstrate how our method can be used to predict the emission properties of novel molecules.

We study phase transitions affected by noise, where these systems exhibit multiplicative white Gaussian noise, Poisson noise, or Lévy noise.
We indicate that for these three types of noise, there exists an optimal noise intensity at which the system undergoes a transition, exhibiting better performance than when there is no noise.
The optimal noise intensity varies depending on whether we consider additive noise or multiplicative noise.
For multiplicative noise, they also depend on the shape of the power spectral density (PSD) of the noise.
Specifically, if the power spectral density has a peak near zero frequency, then as the width of this peak increases, the optimal noise intensity will decrease.
If the power spectral density (PSD) does not have such a peak and instead monotonically decays to zero frequency, then as the decay rate slows down, the optimal noise intensity will increase.

Finally, if the decay rate of the power spectral density (PSD) is faster than exponential decay, then the optimal noise intensity will remain constant and will not depend on the decay rate of the PSD.

We consider the problem of energy-efficient resource allocation in wireless networks under quality of service (QoS) constraints, where each user has individual QoS requirements and is equipped with multiple radio devices to enable simultaneous communication on different channels.
We proposed a novel framework that jointly optimizes power control, channel allocation, scheduling, and routing, and formulates it as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) problem.
The proposed Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) model takes into account the interference between users within the same base station as well as the interference between adjacent base stations.
In order to efficiently solve this large-scale optimization problem, we have developed two efficient algorithms based on Lagrangian relaxation techniques.
Our simulation results indicate that, compared to existing solutions, the algorithm we propose can significantly improve network performance.

Especially when there are only a few active links in each cell at every moment, our solution achieves a throughput that is up to 4 times higher than that of the baseline scheme, without the need to increase transmission power or bandwidth.
Keywords: energy efficiency, power control, channel allocation, scheduling.

We have performed the first next-to-leading order (NLO) calculation of quark-quark scattering within the framework of Multi-Parton Interactions (MPI).
We demonstrate that this process is primarily dominated by gluons and quarks with smaller transverse momentum, which are generated through initial state radiation from one or two incoming hadrons.
The cross section for quark-quark scattering can be expressed as the product of the integral of the transverse momentum distribution of these radiated particles and their squared matrix elements.
This enables us to use standard Monte Carlo techniques to calculate the total cross section.

We present results from two different galaxy formation models: one is a stable model, where there is no merger or mass growth of dark matter halos (the standard cold dark matter model), and the other is an unstable model, where dark matter halos continue to merge to form larger structures.
We use these models to study how the Milky Way evolves over time, as it is influenced by the mergers between host dark matter halos.
The merging rate was higher earlier on, when there were more small halos that could be merged into large halos.
In our unstable model, we found that most massive galaxies have undergone several major mergers since z = 1, while smaller mass galaxies have experienced fewer mergers.
Our results indicate that since z=1, the number density of the brightest galaxy clusters has significantly increased through the merger of galaxy clusters.
This growth can be explained by the development of the brightest star cluster galaxies through mergers, rather than simply forming from gas cooling in the hot intergalactic medium.

We analyzed the stability of planetary systems in which the protoplanetary embryos evolve in a oligarchic state, meaning they can scatter each other’s neighbors through gravitational interactions but are unable to self-scatter.
We found that this process leads to the rapid growth of the largest embryo until it reaches its isolated mass (the minimum mass required for chain accretion).
The system then evolves into either a single planet or two planets of comparable mass, depending on the proximity of the initial conditions to instability.

This evolution is very different from the situation that occurs when all objects grow simultaneously; in particular, we demonstrate that multiple stable outcomes may arise even when the initial conditions are the same.
Our results indicate that the formation of terrestrial planets may have undergone multiple stages, including oligarchic growth, before reaching the final state observed today.
In addition, our research provides new insights into the origin of sub-Neptune planets.
The original planetary embryos form in the protoplanetary disk of a young star and experience mutual gravitational interactions during their growth phase.
These interactions can lead to orbital migration and dynamical instability, such as collisions between adjacent embryos.
Because these processes occur frequently enough, ultimately only one celestial body will survive at the end of the growth phase, leaving behind a planetary system consisting of just one planet.
However, recent research shows that many planetary systems contain multiple planets, suggesting that there must be some mechanism in place to prevent the complete destruction of the system.

Here, we study whether protoplanetary embryos follow a layered evolutionary path, that is, they first grow in a layered manner through gravitational scattering, and then, after the largest embryos reach their independent mass, they enter an uncontrolled accumulation phase.
Through numerical simulation, we have demonstrated that this scenario naturally explains the existence of multi-planet systems, while also reproducing the characteristics of known exoplanets.

In this work, we study the throughput capacity region of multi-hop wireless networks with multiple transmitters and one receiver (MISO-MHWN).
We first prove that the MISO-MHWN is equivalent to an interference channel, where each transmitter has only one antenna but can communicate simultaneously with all receivers in the network.

Then, by using the concept of degrees of freedom (DoF), which characterizes how many parallel data streams can be supported under high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions, we derive the outer boundary of the DoF region for MISO-MHWNS.
Finally, based on these results, we propose a novel transmission scheme called "Interference Alignment (IA)" to achieve the optimal degrees of freedom region.
The proposed IA scheme leverages spatial reuse gain and multi-user diversity gain.
In particular, it allows different users to transmit their signals over non-overlapping time-frequency resources while maintaining complete spatial reuse among them.

We study how classical and quantum uncertainty influence price dynamics in an incomplete information environment, where participants have access to different information sources regarding the underlying state variables.

We prove that when traders do not have a common understanding of the true value of state variables, even if everyone is rational and risk-neutral, they may have different expectations about their future evolution.
This discrepancy can lead to price fluctuations, which may be exacerbated by the presence of noise traders, whose trades are based entirely on their private signals.
In this case, we find that stock returns exhibit volatility clustering and heavy tail characteristics, which are similar to the empirically observed situation.
Finally, we proved that these effects can persist in both classical and quantum states with non-Gaussian statistics.
The results presented here provide new insights into the role that uncertainty plays in shaping the statistical properties of asset returns.
They also suggested possible avenues for further research in order to understand the origins of this phenomenon within more realistic trading behavior models.

1 Introduction  
The intense energy release of solar flares causes rapid changes in the physical conditions of the solar atmosphere.
These include temperatures rising to millions of Kelvin, strong magnetic fields, high density, and great velocities.
All these factors can affect the shape of the spectral lines emitted by different atmospheric layers.

For example, it has been demonstrated that the strength ratio between two iron I lines formed at different temperatures depends on the formation height of each line (Feldman et al., 1995; Brosius & Phillips, 2004).

In addition, the presence of non-thermal electrons leads to a significant deviation of the Maxwellian speed distribution, resulting in asymmetric spectral line features (e.g., Canfield et al. 1990; Doschek et al. 1991), while large-scale flows cause a Doppler shift in the center position of the spectral lines (Doschek et al. 1991; Brosius and Phillips 2004; Brosius 2009).
Therefore, studying the evolution of the line profile over time provides important information about the dynamics of the flaring region.
However, interpreting these data requires a detailed understanding of the fundamental physical knowledge involved in the processes that lead to the observed phenomena.
In particular, the study of the Mg II h & k lines provides a unique opportunity to investigate various aspects of solar flares, as they form over a wide range.

In this article, we study the broadcast problem in multi-hop wireless networks with random access.
Specifically, each node maintains a data packet that ultimately needs to be transmitted to every other node in the network.
Each node independently and uniformly selects a starting time slot to begin transmitting its data packets.
If two or more nodes begin transmission in the same time slot, these transmissions will collide, causing them to both fail to successfully reach their intended recipient.
Our goal is to design distributed algorithms that achieve stability and high throughput by minimizing the number of retransmissions required to pass messages.

We propose an algorithm to solve the half-space depth problem, which is one of the fundamental problems in computational geometry.
The input includes n points in the plane with integer coordinates, which are constrained by B.
We want to find a point such that its distance to all other points is minimized.

We study the weighted complexity function W(G), which is applicable to a graph G with n vertices. This function is defined as the minimum number of edges in any subgraph H with n vertices, such that H contains all cycles of length at most k (where k = 3, ..., n).

We prove the upper bound of this function by using the concept of the determinant of the adjacency matrix A associated with graph G. In particular, we show that if A has no zero rows or zero columns, then W(G) ≤ 2n - 1.
This boundary can be improved when A meets certain additional conditions.
Finally, we provide examples to demonstrate that our results are accurate.

The expression \( W(G; k) \) for \( k = 3, \ldots, n \) was introduced by Chartrand et al. and measures the minimum number of edges required to make every cycle of length at most \( k \) in a given graph \( G \). Recent research has shown that for any connected, triangle-free planar graph \( G \), \( W(G; 3) = n - 2 \).
At this point, we improve these results by proving that for any connected planar graph G without triangles, \( W(G;3) \leq n-1 \).

We propose that dark matter in the galaxy is an effective four-dimensional manifestation of extra dimensions and demonstrate how this can be achieved in a simple model that includes an extra dimension compactified on S^1/Z_2.
At both ends of the fifth dimension, there are two three-dimensional membranes connected by a volumetric scalar field.
We found that the scalar field forms a distorted profile in the fifth dimension, which is caused by the presence of a barrier between the two membranes.
This leads to a localized fermion mass term applicable to the fermions located on the visible (3-) surface, thereby producing a phenomenologically viable dark matter candidate.
In addition, there is another type of particle called the Kaluza-Klein mode, whose mass depends on the size of the extra dimensions.
These KK states do not interact with the standard model fields at tree level, but they do make significant contributions to loop processes (such as neutrino oscillations or proton decay).
Finally, we discussed the experimental characteristics that might arise in our context.

We study the nonlinear evolution of large-scale magnetic fields (LSMFs) in two dimensions through direct numerical simulations of incompressible magnetohydrodynamics with periodic boundary conditions.
We found that large-scale moving bodies (LSMFs) are spontaneously generated through a reverse cascading process, which is similar to three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence.
However, we also observed some differences between the two-dimensional and three-dimensional cases.
Specifically, the energy spectrum of LSMF has an exponential tail at large wave numbers, rather than the power-law behavior observed in the 3D case.
The source of this difference can be understood by considering the impact of magnetic helicity conservation on the dynamics of large-scale magnetic fields (LSMF).
In addition, we demonstrate that the effective drift speed of LSMF largely depends on its initial configuration.
Finally, we discussed the potential applications of our results in solar physics.

This article is based on the results of field research conducted by the author over the past decade and provides new data on the paleogeography and geodynamics of the Russian Arctic region during the late Quaternary period.
The research area is located between the Liena River to the west and the Colmar River to the east (Figure 1).

We reported on electrical transport measurements conducted through individual diphenyl disulfide molecules, which were connected to gold electrodes using the scanning tunneling microscope break-junction technique. The measurements were performed at room temperature (RT) and at low temperatures down to 4 K. The current-voltage characteristics exhibit distinct features of molecular conductivity, such as Coulomb blockade peaks and regions of negative differential resistance.
We found that the junction conductivity strongly depends on the angle between the molecular skeleton and the substrate normal.
This can be explained by the anisotropic coupling strength between the molecules and the metal, which leads to different transmission probabilities along the two principal axes of the molecules.
Furthermore, we observed that the conductivity has a strong temperature dependence, peaking at around 50 K. These results are discussed in a model based on the electron-phonon scattering process.

Additionally, we observed several small-scale brightenings around the main sunspot before the onset of flare/coronal mass ejection activities.
These brightening areas are identified as eruptive regions (ERs), known to play an important role in triggering eruptions such as flares or coronal mass ejections (CMEs).
By analyzing high-resolution images captured by Hinode/SOT/SP, we demonstrate that these arch filaments (ER) interact intensely with the surrounding magnetic field lines during rapid rotation.
This interaction leads to the reconnection of open and closed magnetic fields, resulting in the formation of current sheets beneath the ER.
Then, when the current sheet becomes unstable due to bending instability, the eruption begins.

We study the phenomenology behind the compactification of large extra dimensions, with a focus on supersymmetric particles, whose mass range can be detected in current experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).
We considered two types of models that are inspired by recent developments in string theory: weakly coupled heterogeneous spaces and strongly coupled type IIB orientifold constructions.
In these two cases, we found an interesting interaction between Kaluza-Klein excitations associated with extra dimensions and the lightest supersymmetric partners of the Standard Model.

For example, in certain regions of parameter space, gluons or quarks may be produced directly through the Drell-Yan process; alternatively, these particles can decay into lighter supersymmetric particles of the Standard Model and then gradually transform into the LSP neutralino.
The generated collider signals are very sensitive to the details of the underlying model parameters as well as the number of extra dimensions.
The variable star single observation program is an open-source software package used for astronomical data analysis.
It was developed by members of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in collaboration with researchers from other institutions around the world.

The goal of this project is to provide a single tool that can analyze all types of astronomical datasets, including photometric time series, spectral observations, images, and more, using advanced techniques such as image subtraction, cross-correlation, period-finding algorithms, and spectral line fitting.
The software has been released under the GNU General Public License version 3 and can be found on GitHub at the following URL: https://github.com/VariableStar/one-shot-astro.
One Shot Astro includes several tools that are very useful for quickly and efficiently analyzing large amounts of astronomical data.

These include a one-shot data cleaning tool (one-shot-datacleaner), which performs automated quality control checks on raw data files; a one-shot mosaic tool (one-shot-mosaic), which creates mosaic images using multiple jittered exposures; a one-shot astrometry tool (one-shot-astrometry), which determines astrometric solutions for a single frame or an entire mosaic image; a one-shot photometry tool (one-shot-photometry), which measures the flux and/or brightness of stars within the field of view; a one-shot data processing pipeline (one-shot-pipeline), which automates the process of running these different tasks together; and a one-shot wikimapia tool (one-shot-wikimapia), which allows users to create custom star maps based on their own object catalogs.

In addition to these core packages, there are many additional modules available through the one-shot-astro repository, which allow users to perform more specialized analyses. For example, one-shot-catalog provides access to various different astrophysical databases through SQL queries; one-shot-fastphot uses machine learning methods to measure stars.
We discussed the gauge invariance properties of the effective action obtained by eliminating heavy degrees of freedom (such as quarks and gluons) in the supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory.
We indicate that these effects are generally not invariant under local gauge transformations unless certain formal conditions are satisfied.
These results have significant implications for constructing gauge-invariant observables in supersymmetric gauge theory.
They also provided an explanation as to why it is still possible to construct non-trivial superpotentials, even though supersymmetry does not allow any explicit breaking terms at the tree level.

In conclusion, we believe that our research findings can be used to address some perplexing features observed in recent lattice simulations of four-dimensional N = 1 supersymmetric quantum chromodynamics.
The supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory plays an important role in both particle physics and string theory.
Their low-energy dynamics is described by an effective action that includes all quantum corrections arising from integration over heavy fields (such as quarks or gluons).
This effective action has been widely studied in recent years, but there are still many unresolved questions regarding its specific structure.
A specific question is whether this behavior is normatively invariant.
It was pointed out over twenty years ago.
If we only integrate over the heavy fermions, then the resulting effective action is indeed gauge invariant.
However, there are counterexamples where the effective action does not satisfy gauge invariance when a large number of bosonic degrees of freedom are included at the same time [2].
Recently, this issue has attracted new attention due to its significance in understanding non-perturbative phenomena in supersymmetric gauge theories [3, 4].
Through this work, we systematically studied the property of gauge invariance using functional methods.
Our main result is that as long as two conditions are satisfied, the effective action is always invariant under the symmetries, up to the total differential at most.
First of all, the effective action should not include higher-order time derivatives that act on the fields.
Second, the coefficients in front of various operators in the effective action will satisfy certain relationships.
For example, they cannot explicitly rely on the coupling constant g.
"If any condition is violated, the effective function will not be able to maintain the standard."

We present numerical simulation results of the nonlinear evolution of electrostatic waves excited by a local source in a magnetized collisionless plasma with non-uniform density and temperature distributions.
The initial conditions were chosen to closely resemble the experimental conditions observed in the Large Plasma Device (LAPD) facility at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA).

We found that the spectrum is mainly dominated by two different branches, which correspond to different types of waves: the slow mode that propagates along the magnetic field lines and the fast mode that propagates at an inclined angle relative to the magnetic field B.

In addition, we have observed some other interesting phenomena, such as the generation of coherent structures and the formation of shock fronts, all of which can be explained within the framework of Zakharov's Langmuir turbulence theory.
Keywords: Nonlinear dynamics; turbulence; wave-particle interactions; collisionless plasma; LAPD; fast-slow mode coupling; fluctuations.
We conducted a comprehensive visible spectrum study of all known Jupiter Trojan asteroids (JTs) for the first time.
We obtained high-resolution spectra from Subaru/HDS, Gemini/GNIRS, and Keck/NIRC-2 to determine their surface compositions.
The sample includes 49 JTs, among which are two new discoveries from our team.
Our analysis shows that the vast majority of JTs are S-type or C-type asteroids.
However, we discovered four celestial bodies that exhibit anomalous spectral characteristics; one of them is an E-type asteroid, while the other three have featureless red sloped continuous spectra.
These objects may be primitive celestial bodies, such as carbonaceous chondrite meteorites.
In addition, we found that some connectomes belong to the dynamic cold family.
This indicates that these families were recently formed through catastrophic collisions between their maternal bodies.
Finally, we discussed the possible formation scenarios of JTs based on our research findings.
Keywords: Asteroid
We consider a periodic oscillation of an adiabatic piston that is in contact with two ideal gases at different temperatures and pressures, separated by a rigid wall.
We prove that if the initial state is close to the equilibrium state, then there exists a unique global solution that converges to its limit cycle at an exponentially fast rate over time.
The proof relies on the combination of techniques from nonlinear analysis (Lyapunov functions) and dynamic theory (Boltzmann equation).
From this work, we studied the dynamics of an adiabatic gas piston system, which consists of a one-dimensional ideal gas sandwiched between two walls.
One side of these walls is fixed, while the other side moves periodically according to certain specified rules.
This problem has been widely studied since the pioneering work of Maxwell, Boltzmann, and Sakur-Tetrode.
Cercignani [Cerc] rigorously proved that, under appropriate assumptions regarding piston motion, the convergence rate of the solutions approaches their limiting cycle exponentially fast.
However, it seems difficult to extend his results to the case where the temperature difference across the pistons always remains small.
Here, we demonstrate how to overcome this difficulty by utilizing new ideas based on Lyapunov functions and estimates derived from dynamical systems theory.
We present the absolute calibration results in the MIPS 24, 70, and 160 micron bands, which were obtained by observing Neptune during its southern hemisphere winter.
We found that our luminosity model has an accuracy exceeding 5% across all three wavelengths in most field of views (FOV).
The uncertainty of the absolute flux scale is primarily dominated by the uncertainty of the Neptune model used as the calibrator.
These are estimated to be less than 10% in each bandpass.
In addition, we characterized the detector response function using the data obtained during the spacecraft testing period before launch.
This feature description has been incorporated into the final processing workflow, which will generate calibration images for scientific research.
Finally, we demonstrate how to combine these results with those presented in Paper I to provide an overall estimate of the accuracy of the MIPS instrument.
Keywords: space science instruments, infrared space telescope, Spitzer Space Telescope, MIPS
We study the resonance spin polarization (RSP) in a two-dimensional hole gas with Rashba spin-orbit coupling by solving the Kohn-Sham equations within density functional theory.
We indicate that the RSP is strongly influenced by the Luttinger parameter, which describes the strength of electron-electron interactions.
Especially, we found that for large values of the Ruthenium parameter, the amplitude of the RSP significantly decreases, which is mainly due to the increase in the effective mass of the holes.
In addition, we have demonstrated that by applying an external electric field perpendicular to the two-dimensional pore gas plane, we can control the RSP.
Finally, we discuss the relationship between our results and recent experiments on GaAs quantum wells.
The influence of the Luttinger term, structure inversion asymmetry (SIA), and Zeeman splitting on resonant spin polarization (RSP) was studied using density functional theory.
It has been found that when the Luttinger parameter increases, the RS P is suppressed, as this leads to a greater effective mass.
In addition, research shows that the RS P can be adjusted by applying an external electric field perpendicular to the plane of the two-dimensional pore gas.
Our results were compared with the recently obtained experimental data of GaAs quantum wells.

Resonant spin polarization (RSP) refers to the generation of a non-equilibrium spin population through optical excitation to the resonant state of heavy hole excitons in zero magnetic field, which has attracted considerable attention in recent years [1-3].

This phenomenon occurs when the energy difference between the lowest energy level of the conduction band and the highest energy level of the valence band is lower than the photon energy of the excitation laser light, as shown in Figure 1(a).
Due to this situation, electrons excited to the conduction band have a limited probability of being scattered back to the valence band before radiative or non-radiative relaxation occurs [5].
If these electrons return to their original state after scattering, they will carry away angular momentum.
Therefore, the total angular momentum of the system is unbalanced.
Recently, several groups reported measurement results for R SP.

We present the results of hydrodynamic simulations that show how supernova ejecta interacts with nearby protoplanetary disks, producing observable features in their infrared emission.

We found that, based on the characteristics of the disks (mass, radius), the interactions may lead to an increase or decrease in the total luminosity emitted by the system at near-infrared wavelengths.
The effect is strongest in large disks around young stars; as the mass ratio of the star to its disk decreases, the effect quickly weakens.
Furthermore, we found that this interaction leads to a significant change in the temperature distribution within the disk.
These effects are most pronounced when the distance to the supernova progenitor is relatively close—less than 100 AU.
In more distant systems, the impact of supernova shock waves becomes negligible.
Finally, our model suggests that the excess mid-infrared flux observed in some T Tauri stars may be due to this interaction.
We analyzed the archived XMM-Newton data of Seyfert 1 galaxy Mkr841 (NGC 4151).
We found that the soft excess radiation can be well described by a blackbody component with a temperature of kT = 0.16 keV and a luminosity of LBB approximately 10^43 erg s^-1.
The hard X-ray spectrum can be fitted using a power law or a Compton reflection model.
In these two cases, we detected a strong relativistic iron Kα line located at 6.4-6.7 keV, with a width broadened to a full width at half maximum of approximately 1000 km/s.
These results suggest that there may be two different regions where the accretion disk interacts with the central supermassive black hole.

One region produces soft excess through thermal processes, while another region generates hard X-ray emission through non-thermal processes, such as inverse Compton scattering and/or Compton reflection.

The first X-ray pulsar Scorpius X-1 (Sco-X1), discovered by Giacconi et al. in 1962, opened an exciting new field in astrophysics and led to the development of many important concepts, such as the accretion disks around compact objects.

The study of these systems underwent a revolutionary change with the launch of the Chandra and XMM-Newton observatories, allowing us to detect their physical properties on an unprecedented spatial scale.
In this review, we will discuss some recent results obtained using these satellites, which reveal how neutron stars form and evolve in low-mass binary systems.
We will also introduce our current understanding of the physics behind the formation of relativistic jets observed in several types of X-ray binaries.
Finally, we will briefly describe future missions, such as XEUS or Constellation-X, which offer prospects for studying these fascinating celestial objects.

We report the detection and characterization of two new types of radio sources in a nearby star formation region, which we identify as candidate young stellar objects (YSOs).

The first type consists of compact radio sources with flat or inverted spectral indices, which are associated with infrared dark clouds (IRDCs); these may be young stellar objects (YSOs) deeply embedded in star formation regions or H II regions undergoing free-free absorption.

The second category includes extended radio sources with steep spectra, which appear to be physically related to infrared dark clouds (IRDCs); they may represent ionized outflows driven by massive protostellar jets.
We also provide evidence that some of our candidates are likely to be magnetically active stars.
These results demonstrate how VLBI observations are used to search for and characterize protostars in their early evolutionary stages.
Keywords: radio astronomy, young stellar objects, infrared dark clouds, magnetars, coronal mass ejections.
We report the analysis of the Chandra archival data for the galaxy cluster Sersic 159-03, which indicates an excess of X-ray emission below 1 keV (i.e., a "soft excess").

We found that this feature is inconsistent with line emissions related to thermal bremsstrahlung or any known atomic species, so we conclude that it must be caused by other processes, such as inverse Compton scattering of relativistic electrons.

The observed spectrum can be well fitted by an absorbed power-law model plus a blackbody component with a temperature of kT = 0.2 keV; however, compared to a more physically motivated model that includes Bremsstrahlung and inverse Compton radiation, we show that this fit is statistically unacceptable.
In particular, we have demonstrated that introducing a second blackbody component significantly improves the fitting quality compared to previous results.
Using these new results, we estimate the total luminosity of the soft excess to be Lx ~ 10^45 erg s^-1 within a radius of R500 = 2 Mpc.
This value can rival the full-band luminosity inferred from several nearby radio halos detected through its synchrotron radiation emission.
We conducted a study on the orbital stability of the 14 planetary systems discovered around the star HD 10180 (HIP 108427) through HATNet and the Kepler space telescope.
We use numerical integration to demonstrate that the system is dynamically stable over a timescale exceeding its age, which we estimate to be 4 billion years through rotational chronology.
These planets have been found to be in two resonant chains, with period ratios close to 2:1 and 3:2.
These chains are interconnected through the resonance chain of uniform motion between adjacent planetary pairs.
This structure indicates that the system is formed within the envelope of each planet through convergent migration and subsequent tidal dissipation.

Keywords: planetary system - stability - mean motion resonance - convergent migration - tides - rotational chronometry - HD10180 - Kepler telescope - HATNet telescope - orbital dynamics - dynamical evolution.
We presented our research findings on the existence and stability of potentially terrestrial planets located around the star Gliese 581, which is approximately 20 light years away from Earth.
We performed numerical simulations of three hypothetical Earth-like planets located in different orbital configurations, with masses ranging from 1 to 10 times that of Earth (1-10 M⊕).
Our calculations indicate that these systems are dynamically stable over timescales exceeding 100 million years.
The largest planet has an eccentric orbit with an eccentricity of e = 0.2, and its periapsis distance varies between 0.05 AU and 0.15 AU, depending on the initial conditions used.
This planet can be considered a hot Jupiter-like planet because it orbits very closely to its host star.
However, we discovered another region where two or more terrestrial planets can stably exist.
In this region, one of them will be a super-Earth type planet, with a mass greater than 5M⊕ but less than 8M⊕.
We report an experimental demonstration of frequency upshift using a relativistic flying mirror (RFM) in two colliding laser pulses.
RFM is implemented as an ultra-thin foil, which is accelerated to high speeds by being focused with intense femtosecond laser pulses at nearly parallel incidence angles.

Our research results indicate that high-energy photons can be produced by the collision of laser pulses in a vacuum.

In recent years, there has been a growing interest in studying the interaction of ultra-intense lasers with matter under extreme conditions.

We introduce the concept of generalized conditional random fields (GCRFs) and demonstrate how they can be used to model arbitrary probability distributions for structured datasets such as sequences or trees.
We propose an efficient algorithm to learn GCRF parameters by performing gradient descent on the log-likelihood objective function.

Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) (Lafferty et al., 2001) are an undirected graphical model that has been successfully applied to many problems involving sequential data, such as (Sha & Pereira, 2003).

In this work, we propose generalized conditional random fields (GCRFs), which are a generalization of conditional random fields that allows us to represent distributions over any structured dataset (such as sequences or trees).
The key idea of GCRFs is to use a set of latent variables to capture the dependencies between different parts of the input space.
This allows us to efficiently compute the partition function required for standard conditional random fields using dynamic programming techniques.
In addition, this also makes it possible to use gradient-based methods similar to Maximum Entropy Markov Models (MEMMs) to train Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs).
To evaluate the performance of our method, we applied it to two important application areas: part-of-speech tagging.

1 Introduction

Data compression has been extensively researched over the past few decades due to its significant importance in many applications such as digital storage systems, communication networks, and medical imaging.
A fundamental problem in data compression is how to accurately predict the size of the compressed file for a given raw uncompressed data.
This problem is commonly referred to as rate-distortion analysis.
As is well known, the rate-distortion function characterizes the relationship between the average codeword length achieved by any optimal coding scheme and the level of distortion.
The most commonly used method for solving rate constraint optimization problems is Lagrangian relaxation.
The method of transforming a constrained optimization problem into an unconstrained optimization problem is by introducing additional variables known as Lagrange multipliers.

The difference between these two methods increases as we enter smaller spatial scales.
We also found that the magnetic field is more inclined towards the surface of the Sun on smaller spatial scales, while the opposite is true on larger scales.
These results suggest that there may be some unknown physical processes affecting the formation of Stokes V profiles on small spatial scales.
This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Research Fund, grant number 16340040.
Introduction: The solar atmosphere is composed of various structures such as sunspots, holes, faculae, and the corona, where different physical phenomena occur.
In order to understand how these phenomena occur, it is important to study their properties individually.
However, this task has always been difficult because most of them have very intricate structures, and they often overlap in space.

To overcome this difficulty, many observational studies have recently been conducted using high-resolution instruments, such as the Swedish 1-meter Solar Telescope (SST), the New Solar Telescope (NST), the Advanced Technology Solar Telescope (ATST), and the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO).

Among them, the Hinode satellite, launched in 2006, provides us with unprecedented high-quality data due to its advanced instruments, including the Spectro-Polarimeter (SP) (Lites et al., 2001) and the Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI) (Schou et al., 2010), enabling us to study the solar photosphere with subarcsecond resolution.

Using these datasets, several authors studied the photospheric magnetic field (for example, Ichimoto et al. (2007), Ishikawa & Tsuneta (2008), Kitai et al. (2009), Orozco Suárez et al. (2010), Sheminova et al. (2011)).
We report the discovery of an extremely bright and hot (effective temperature T_eff = 300,000 K) blue supergiant in the cluster NGC 6231, with a mass loss rate of 10^-6 M_sun/year.
The object is located 1 kiloparsec (kpc) from Earth, with a luminosity of 5 x 10^{5} L_Sun.
It shows strong emission lines from He II 4686 Å, N III 4641 Å, C IV 5801 Å, O V 7322 Å, and the H Balmer series.
We suggest that this celestial body may be a member of the Cygnus OB2 star cluster, which contains several other high-quality stars.
This will make it one of the brightest single stars known outside our galaxy.
If confirmed through further observations, this celestial body will provide important constraints for the stellar evolution models of massive stars.
Keywords: open clusters; blue supergiants

We present results from infrared sources selected based on their flux density at a wavelength of 11 micrometers (S11). These data were collected early using the infrared camera (IRC) on the AKARI infrared space telescope, which was launched into orbit in February 2006.
The survey covered an area of approximately 1 square degree, centered at the north ecliptic pole, achieving a signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) limit of 5 for point source detection.
We have identified more than 1,000 infrared sources across the entire field of view, reaching S11 ~ 0.1 Jy.
Among them, we found that most are associated with galaxies or galaxy clusters.
Approximately 20% of these objects exhibit red colors, indicating the presence of dust obscuring stellar formation activity.
The remaining 80% shows a significant portion in blue, indicating active galactic nuclei and/or young star populations.

These results indicate that our sample includes various types of infrared-emitting objects, including normal galaxies, interacting/merging systems, obscured active galactic nuclei (AGN), and distant quasars.
We consider the problem of estimating the unknown function f from the noise measurement y = Af + w, where A is a linear operator and w is white noise with a known covariance matrix Cw.
We assume that operator A has been discretized on some grid (for example, by using finite difference or spectral methods) so that it can be represented as a large matrix.
The goal is to find an estimate \( \hat{f} \) that minimizes \( E[\hat{f} - f]^2 \) under certain restrictions on the smoothness of \( f \).
Based on this work, we proposed a new numerical technique based on the need function, which can efficiently solve these constrained optimization problems.

In particular, our approach allows us to obtain accurate estimates even when the number of available observations \( N \) is much smaller than the dimension \( M \) of the space spanned by the columns of \( A \). The proposed method relies on two main components:
First, we use demand function-based sparse representation.
Secondly, we developed efficient iterative algorithms to solve ultra-large-scale convex optimization problems involving sparse promoting regularization.
These algorithms combine the ideas of compressed sensing theory with the latest results on the convergence rate of the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM).

We report on the electronic structure and magnetic properties of zigzag graphene nanoribbons (ZGNR) with different edge structures, including hydrogenated ZGNR (H-ZGNR), fluorinated ZGNR (F-ZGNR), oxidized ZGNR (O-ZGNR), and nitrogen-doped oxidized ZGNR (N-ZGNR).
We found that all these ZGNRs are semimetallic except for H-ZGNR, which is metallic.
The band gaps of F-ZGNR and N-ZGNR increase compared to the original ZGNR, which is due to the difference in electronegativity between the edge carbon atoms and their neighboring atoms.
On the contrary, when an oxygen atom replaces one or two carbon atoms at each edge, the band gap slightly decreases because the oxygen atom transfers charge to the neighboring carbon atoms.
Our results indicate that introducing oxygen elements at the edges of zigzag graphene nanoribbons can enhance spin polarization.
We propose a decision tree learning method that utilizes data views to enhance efficiency and scalability.
The proposed method is based on the concept of using multiple perspectives, with each perspective capturing different aspects or characteristics of the same dataset.
We demonstrate how to achieve this by defining a set of views for each node of the decision tree model during learning.
These views were subsequently used as inputs for a modified standard ID3 algorithm that learns decision tree structures.
Our experimental results indicate that there are significant improvements in both accuracy and execution time compared to existing methods.
Decision trees are widely used in various fields such as classification, regression analysis, clustering, and association rule mining due to their simplicity and effectiveness.
However, they have two main drawbacks: (1) high computational cost; (2) poor scalability.
Specifically, at any given internal node, the number of possible splits grows exponentially with the size of the training samples of its parent node.
This makes it difficult to efficiently design large decision trees.
To address these issues, we propose a new method called Relational View-based Decision Tree Learning (RV-DTL).
RV-DTL is based on the concept of multi-view learning, where each view captures certain aspects of the original data.
More specifically, our method defines a set of views for each internal node in the decision tree under construction.
Each view corresponds to a specific subset of features associated with the corresponding node.
Then, RV-DTL does not build the entire decision tree from scratch; instead, it starts from smaller subtrees with leaf nodes as roots and gradually expands upward until all leaf nodes are reached.
In each expansion step, RV-DTL selects the best split from the available splits based on the information gain criterion.
Finally, the final decision tree is constructed through merging.
The clustering properties of light nuclei are studied within the framework of the relativistic fragmentation model (RFM).
The foundation of RFM is the concept that nuclear matter can be regarded as a collection of clusters that interact through an effective potential.
In this work, we used the recently developed microscopic cluster-cluster interaction potential to describe light nuclei at low energies.
We demonstrate that RFM well reproduces the experimental data on the production cross-sections of different fragments in medium-energy heavy-ion collisions.
Keywords: clustering; fragmentation; light core; relativistic approach; heavy ions; microscopic interactions.

1 Introduction  
The study of nuclear structure plays an important role in understanding many phenomena observed in nuclear physics experiments [1].
One of these phenomena is the clustering effect, which is the tendency to form bound states composed of multiple particles or even larger systems, such as α particles.
In recent years, there has been considerable interest in the study of clustering effects in light nuclei.
Research shows that the clustering phenomenon plays an important role in describing the ground state properties of light nuclei, such as binding energy and charge radius.
In addition, studies have found that the clustering effect also significantly influences the reaction kinetics of light nuclei.
For example, the formation probability of compound nuclei in fusion reactions is closely related to the number of clusters present in the incoming channel [11].
Therefore, when studying the mechanisms of light nuclear reactions, it is essential to consider the collective degrees of freedom.

We propose an algorithm to find optimal hierarchical descriptors (OHDs), which can be used as fingerprints in complex networks, such as social and biological systems.
OHD represents a network structure of varying granularity, using a tree-like structure where nodes represent sub-networks or clusters.

The Standard Model is highly consistent with all current experimental data, yet it still leaves many unsolved mysteries and has not been able to explain some phenomena observed in experiments.

The muon magnetic moment anomaly provides an example of this: there is a significant discrepancy between theoretical predictions and experimental measurements, which cannot be explained within the framework of the standard model.

In this presentation, I will introduce the physical background of the new g-2 experiment at Fermilab, which aims to measure the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon more accurately by using a new method based on laser cooling and trapping techniques developed in recent years.
This speech introduces the physical rationale behind the proposed new measurement of the muon anomalous magnetic moment at Fermilab.
It describes how the use of laser cooling and trapping significantly improves precision compared to previous experiments.
Several other topics related to the project were also discussed, including the status of the R&D project, with the goal of measuring the muon magnetic moment to an accuracy of 0.5 parts per million.

The dielectric properties, phase transition behavior, and microstructural evolution of (0.65[Pb(Ni-1/3Nb-2/3)O_3] -0.35PbTiO3) (PNT) ceramics were studied at different sintering temperatures ranging from 850 to 1100 °C.

The PNT samples exhibit a high dielectric constant value below approximately 10^4, a low loss tangent below 10^-2, and have a greater tunability of over 30% under an electric field strength of 30 kV/cm at room temperature.
As the temperature decreases to 77 K, the dielectric constant slightly increases, while the loss tangent significantly decreases, which is mainly due to the freezing of mobile ions.
Under low-temperature conditions, two relaxation processes were observed in the frequency range from 1 Hz to 100 kHz.
The first process is attributed to the grain boundary effect; as the temperature decreases, it shifts to higher frequencies.
The second process is related to the movement of ferroelectric domain walls; when the temperature changes, its relaxation time constant remains almost unchanged.
We studied the ground state properties of the frustrated spin-1/2 Heisenberg model on a square lattice under different types of inter-layer coupling, including both uniform and non-uniform coupling.
