The obtained results were discussed within the framework of the recently proposed concept of "inverse condensation."

We present the results of first-principles calculations, including the structure, electronic, and magnetic properties of LaMnO3 in its rhombohedral phase (R3c).
We demonstrated that the local spin density approximation (LSDA) fails to accurately reproduce the lattice constant and band gap energy.
Compared to the experiments, the latter has been underestimated by more than an order of magnitude.
In contrast, our self-consistent full-field linearized enhanced plane wave method shows good consistency between the calculated values of these quantities and the experimental values.

In order to better understand the source of this difference, we conducted additional calculations using an effective tight-binding approach based on Wannier functions obtained within the LSDA+U formalism.

Our analysis indicates that the main reason LSDA fails to accurately describe the electronic structure of LaMnO3 is the strong mixing effects, which are not adequately accounted for in the standard LSDA framework.

We study the effects of random large-scale forcing on three-dimensional rotational stratified flow using direct numerical simulation (DNS) with periodic boundary conditions.

The flow is enforced on a large scale by adding an external force to the momentum equation, which has an average value of zero but whose Fourier transform contains both positive and negative wave numbers.

The characteristics of vortex modes are that intense vertical motion is concentrated near the center of the region; their horizontal speeds are relatively low, and the kinetic energy rapidly diminishes as one moves away from the center.

On the other hand, the characteristics of the fluctuation pattern include relatively weak vertical motion, distributed over a larger spatial area; they exhibit high horizontal speeds, and their kinetic energy decays slowly or even slightly increases as one moves away from the center.
In addition, these waves can be standing waves or horizontally propagating waves, depending on the peak of the forcing spectrum at small or large horizontal wave numbers.

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were discovered about a decade ago and have attracted widespread attention due to their unique physical properties, such as high electrical conductivity, mechanical strength, thermal stability, and chemical inertness. These characteristics make them promising candidate materials for a variety of potential applications, ranging from field emitter devices to sensors and optoelectronic devices.
However, most of their practical applications require carbon nanotube networks with controllable orientation and density.
In recent years, several methods for preparing oriented carbon nanotube films have been developed.
Among these technologies, Langmuir-Blodgett (LB) deposition has become one of the most powerful methods.
This process involves spreading a monolayer of amphiphilic molecules at the air-water interface, and then vertically immersing a hydrophobic substrate into the aqueous phase.
By repeating the steps outlined above, a multilayer film composed of densely packed carbon nanotubes (CNTs) can be obtained.

Compared to other methods, LB deposition has several advantages, such as the ability to precisely control the layer thickness, ease of producing large, homogeneous films, and the capability to create patterned structures.
We report on X-ray timing observations of the pulsar candidate PSR J1930+1855 located at the center of the supernova remnant (SNR) G54.1+0.
The source was discovered by Chandra and confirmed as a pulsar by XMM-Newton, but its rotation period is not stable on timescales of over a day.
We conducted a series of targeted RXTE observations to further study this behavior.
In both cases, we found that the pulse frequency steadily decreased during our observations.
This trend can be well described by an exponential decay model, and we found that the corresponding characteristic time scales are 1.1 days and 0.7 days, respectively.
The values are consistent with the results previously reported based solely on Chandra data.

However, it should be noted that when directly comparing these results, the uncertainty involved in previous measurements is significantly larger due to the lower signal-to-noise ratio obtained by Chandra compared to RXTE.

We present the results of numerical simulations aimed at studying the ionized hydrogen (HII) regions that form and evolve around massive stars embedded within an isothermal self-gravitating gas distribution characterized by a power-law density distribution.
We found that the expansion speed of the ionization front decreases as it moves from the position of the star to larger radii.
The reason for the reduction is due to the decrease in density, leading to a smaller pressure gradient when moving outward.
Therefore, the ionization front may become unstable to small disturbances, leading to its fragmentation into several small clumps or filamentary structures.
These objects are surrounded by a dense shell of neutral material, which is generated by the evaporation of light from the surrounding medium.
In addition, we indicate that for large values of the exponent n in the power law density distribution, the mass loss rate significantly increases.
This increase can be explained by the fact that the gravitational force acting on each unit volume of the shell decreases faster than the impact pressure of the expanding bubble.
We present the renormalization group flow equations of quantum gauge fields in curved spacetime, including fermions and scalars, as well as their interactions with gravity.
We indicate that these flows are governed by an exact functional differential equation that is derived through the background field method.
The solution to this equation provides all possible anomalous terms, making the theory finite at any order of perturbation theory.
This result generalizes the previous results obtained in a flat spacetime background.
We found that the beta function of gravity coupling is not zero even when only considering pure Yang-Mills theory without including matter fields.

1. Introduction  
Supermassive black holes are located at the center of most massive galaxies.
Their growth is believed to be driven by gas inflows induced by gravitational torques generated during galaxy mergers and/or interactions (Barnes & Hernquist 1996; Hopkins et al., 2006).
However, it is still unclear what will happen when this fuel supply runs out.

One possibility is that black holes continue to grow through inefficiently radiative accretion flows (Narayan & Yi 1994), which would generate powerful winds and jets capable of driving large-scale flows of material into the surrounding interstellar medium (ISM) (Silk & Rees 1998; Di Matteo et al. 2005).

Another possibility is that black holes may become dormant when the interstellar medium becomes overheated and cannot cool effectively (Bower et al. 2006; Croton et al. 2006), until another merger event triggers new activity.
Understanding the mechanism that controls the growth of black holes will help us understand why some galaxies have supermassive black holes while others do not.

We introduced the concept of covering homology, which is a way to extend ordinary homology to infinite graphs and simplicial complexes.
The main idea of this concept is that we not only consider finite subcomplexes, but also their infinite analogues — the so-called coverings.
We demonstrate how covered homology can be used to study the properties of infinite graphs, such as planarity or hypercurvature.
In particular, we prove that if a graph has infinitely many ends, then its first covering homology group is zero.
This result generalizes Stallings' classical theorem about groups with infinitely many ends.
"Covering homology provides us with new tools to study various kinds of infinite objects in mathematics."

We presented the results of hydrodynamic simulations, which show how planets open gaps in the disk surrounding a star, and determine the minimum mass required for them to open these gaps as a function of the disk's viscosity, surface density profile slope, and the irradiation from the central star.
We found that a planet's ability to open gaps primarily depends on its material accumulation rate (which is related to the planet's mass), rather than its brightness or temperature.

The critical planet mass decreases with the increase in disk viscosity, as higher viscosity leads to faster transport of angular momentum on the planet's orbit, which in turn reduces the planet's ability to accrete gas.

In the case of fixed viscosity, we find that the critical planetary mass increases as the power index of the surface density decreases, because lower values of this parameter correspond to a steeper radial distribution of surface density in the disk, which results in a stronger gravitational torque applied by the planet.
Ultimately, we found that the critical mass of planets decreases with increasing stellar radiation, which is due to the increased temperature caused by most of the torque generated at small radii.

We present the results of a study that investigates the properties and evolution of transients that arise when generating initial conditions using Lagrangian Perturbation Theory (LPT), which are related to cosmological N-body simulations.

We found that the initial conditions based on LPT produce false large-scale energy in the late stage, and this phenomenon does not diminish by increasing the number of particles used to generate these initial conditions.

We propose to extend the fuzzy ball theory of black holes to include internal degrees of freedom, which are excited by infalling matter and generate Hawking radiation.

For our situation, we consider non-extreme black holes, whose entropy matches the number of microstates in a strongly coupled quantum field theory, but now includes internal degrees of freedom.

The MCHIT (Monte Carlo Heavy Ion Transport) code is an advanced tool used to simulate the transport of ions in matter, including their interactions with target nuclei and elastic scattering with atomic electrons.

The Standard Model (SM) is a very successful theory, but there are still many unanswered questions in physics at very high energies.

In particular, there are currently no known fundamental principles that can explain why the Standard Model has three generations of quarks and leptons with such different masses, or how gravity fits into this framework.
Theories beyond the standard model attempt to solve these problems by introducing new particles and/or interactions, which may be observed in future experiments.
Supersymmetry (SUSY) introduces partner particles for all Standard Model (SM) fields that differ in spin by half a unit.

These partner states have the same gauge quantum numbers as their counterparts in the Standard Model, so if supersymmetry is broken at low energy scales, they can mix with the particles of the Standard Model.

Bayesian Networks (BN) are an important category of models used to analyze and predict gene regulatory networks, which describe how genes interact with each other in biological systems.
In this study, we use Bayesian networks as a tool to predict the sequence of events in the cell division process of fission yeast (Schizosaccharomyces pombe).
We constructed two different Bayesian networks using data obtained from microarray experiments conducted on synchronized cultures at four time points in the cell cycle.
The construction of the first BN is based solely on the expression levels of a core set of essential genes that are crucial for cell survival.
The second BN includes all the genes that show significant changes during the cell cycle.
Using these Bayesian networks, we predicted the order of events occurring in the cell cycle.
Our results indicate that these two Bayesian networks (BNs) can accurately reproduce the observed temporal order of the different stages of the cell cycle.
However, when comparing each other, our results indicate that incorporating non-core genes into the Bayesian Network (BN) may lead to more accurate predictions.

We studied the slow wave resonance (SWR) effect of periodically layered media with an arbitrary number N of anisotropic layers, each characterized by its own dielectric constant tensor and thickness.
We prove that surface wave reflection (SWR) can only be achieved when all principal axes of the dielectric tensor in each layer are parallel to each other.
For this situation, we derived an explicit expression for the dispersion relation between frequency f and Bloch wave number kx.
The obtained results can serve as guiding principles for designing multilayer structures that exhibit strong surface wave reflection (SWR) effects at low frequencies.
Keywords: slow-wave resonance; anisotropy; multilayer structure; dispersion relationship.

We study the magnetic field enhancement in supernova remnants (SNRs) caused by the instability of cosmic ray flux. This instability is driven by the anisotropic diffusion of energetic particles along the direction of the average magnetic field lines.
We indicate that this process may be the reason for the magnetic field levels observed in young supernova remnants, and it can explain their origin.
The growth rate of instability depends on the ratio between the cyclotron frequency of relativistic protons and the frequency of the plasma waves they excite.
This ratio decreases over time because the number density of accelerated particles increases downstream of the shock front.
Therefore, the instability saturates after a certain distance ahead of the shock, at which point the magnetic energy density is comparable to the kinetic energy density of the flow.
To estimate the saturation scale, we used an analytical model recently developed by Bell et al. (2013).
It enables us to calculate the spectrum of amplified magnetic fluctuations produced by the instability of cosmic ray flow.
We study the effects of spin-1 and spin-2 particles on the propagation of circularly polarized light through an external magnetic field.

We indicate that this effect is determined by the interaction between photons and particles with zero spin, either one or two, and occurs only when the photon energy exceeds a certain threshold, which depends on the mass of the particles.
For example, for electrons (mass m = 9.11×10^-31 kilograms), this threshold is 0.5 MeV. Below this threshold, there are no effects caused by high-spin particles.
The results obtained can serve as a basis for the development of new methods for studying high-spin particles using optical techniques.

The Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM) is the most widely studied extension of the Standard Model, predicting the existence of new particles that could be discovered in future experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).
In this presentation, I will discuss some of the latest results related to the search for supersymmetry using the data collected during the first phase of the LHC operation in the ATLAS experiment.
The focus will be on the properties of the lightest CP-odd neutral Higgs boson \( h^0 \), which are strongly influenced by radiative corrections from top quark/supersymmetric quark loops.
These effects lead to significant deviations between the predictions based on tree-level calculations and the results obtained from the full one-loop calculations.
This has an important impact on experimental analysis and theoretical studies aimed at extracting fundamental parameters such as tanβ or mtop from measurements at hadron colliders.

For example, we demonstrate how the inclusion of higher-order corrections leads to better consistency between theory and experiment when comparing the measured mass of the Higgs boson with the predicted value within the MSSM framework.
We also presented results on the production cross sections of different decay modes of the Higgs boson, including their dependence on the selected renormalization scale in the calculations.
Finally, we briefly commented on the prospects of searching for the Higgs after the second round of the LHC.
We propose an algorithm for decomposing the local stellar kinematics into vector spherical harmonics (VSH).

This issue is addressed by extending these quantities to vector spherical harmonics (VSH), which are defined as the tensor product of scalar spherical harmonics.

Finally, we discuss the possible origins of this newly buried supermassive black hole based on the observational results.

The space elevator is an important project in future space exploration, and it will provide efficient transportation between Earth's orbit and the surface.
The Electrostatic Climber (EC) is a key component of the space elevator system, designed to transport passengers or cargo up and down along the cable.
In this work, we propose a new design concept for a capacitor (EC) based on the principle of electric dynamic levitation.
According to our proposed design, a prototype has already been built.
It consists of two main parts: an upper platform and a lower platform.
The upper platform contains four permanently arranged magnets arranged in a square formation, while the lower platform consists of eight coils connected in series.
The experimental results show that at a current density of 0.5 A/mm², the maximum lift generated by electrochemistry (EC) is approximately 1 N.
The value meets the requirements for space elevator applications.
In addition, it also demonstrates good stability when there are changes in load.
We proposed an experimental method to measure the slip length of Newtonian fluids at low Reynolds numbers by twisting an ultrasonic oscillator (TUSO).
TUSO is immersed in a liquid and vibrates with an angular frequency.
The torque that causes it to rotate is proportional to the shear stress acting on the surface, which can be electrically detected by a pickup coil wound around the shaft.
We indicate that this rotation will result in a phase lag between the drive voltage and the current passing through the pickup coil.
The phase lag depends on the slip length and other parameters such as the viscosity and density of the surrounding medium.
By fitting our theoretical model to the measured data, we are able to extract the slip length from the data.
Our results are very consistent with previous experiments conducted under similar conditions.
In addition, we demonstrate how the measurement principle proposed here can also be used to measure the slip length of non-Newtonian fluids.

We provide new measurements of the helium mass fraction YHe = 0.24 ± 0.01 (statistical) ± 0.02 (systematic). We study the complexity of model checking higher-order fixed-point logic (HFL) on finite Kripke structures. This is an extended propositional modal logic that includes fixed points and quantification over state variables, with its range covering infinite domains.

We proved that the satisfiability of HFL can be reduced to the problem of determining whether there exists a solution to a system of rational linear equations with coefficients given by a polynomial in integers.
This simplification enables us to leverage the known results regarding the solving of polynomial equation systems to obtain a lower bound on the computational complexity of HFL satisfiability.
Specifically, we prove that when the number of fixed point operators occurring in the formulas is unbounded or limited to existential quantifiers, the satisfiability of HFL is PSPACE-hard.
On the other hand, we provide a simple algorithm to solve HFL satisfiability, which is based on calculating the minimal solutions of certain integer quadratic equations.
The running time of the algorithm is exponentially related to the maximum degree of these equations, but is independent of the number of fixed points.

This study focuses on investigating the wave dynamics of photons through position eigenvectors, which are introduced as solutions to the Schrödinger equation for photons with arbitrary energy spectra.
The concept of position eigenvector allows us to describe the state of a single photon using the probability density distribution function (PDF) of the photon’s positional information.
It also allows us to introduce the concept of quantum trajectories to describe the evolution of the probability density function over time.
In particular, we demonstrate that the quantum trajectories corresponding to different initial states can be obtained from each other through unitary transformations.
We demonstrated how to use these results to analyze various phenomena related to the propagation of light in dispersive media.
Finally, we discussed the potential applications of our method in describing non-classical effects associated with the emission of entangled photon pairs.

We found that heterogeneous populations are more likely to develop complex economic systems, which include specialized production units, markets for goods and services, and labor division among producers, compared to homogeneous populations.

We present new near-infrared (NIR) polarization observations of the GG Tau system, which reveal that the disk surrounding the star has a highly structured nature and contains several bright regions with different polarization characteristics.
The most prominent feature in our dataset is an arch-like structure located approximately 0.5 arc seconds southeast of the central binary star.
The region exhibits strong polarized radiation, reaching 10% of the total intensity, and was previously identified as a reflection nebula by Weintraub et al. (1993).
We found that this feature can be explained by the scattering of optical fine dust particles near the center of the disc.
Through addition, we detected two other bright features on either side of the central binary star.
These are also related to high linear polarization degree, but there is no obvious evidence of scattered light.
On the contrary, they seem to be caused by absorption under the background starlight flux.
Finally, we identified three additional darker structures in the southern part of the disk.
All these features have similar polarization angles, indicating that their origins may be related.

Zero Point Energy (ZPE) is defined as the minimum energy required to create particles from nothing.
Although zero-point energy (ZPE) cannot actually exist because it violates the laws of physics, it does provide useful insights into certain phenomena observed in our universe.

For example, if we consider the early expansion of spacetime in the existence of the universe, it seems reasonable to assume that, with the rapid release of zero-point energy (ZPE), the volume of space grows exponentially over time.
If that is the case, then the overall mass-energy density will quickly decrease until all available zero-point energy is released.
At this stage, the universe will consist solely of vacuum fluctuations, where virtual particles and antiparticles coexist but never interact with each other.
The absence of pleasure is an important symptom of depression and schizophrenia, but its underlying neurobiological mechanisms are still not very clear.
In this study, we investigated whether chronic social defeat (CSD) would lead to anhedonia-like behavior in male C57BL/6J mice.
We found that, compared to the control group, animals exposed to CSD showed a reduced preference for the sucrose solution.
In addition, mice exposed to CSD showed increased immobility time in the forced swimming test, while displaying reduced locomotor activity in the open field test.
Finally, we observed that in the defeated mice, acute administration of amphetamine resulted in a significant decrease in dopamine release in the shell region of the nucleus accumbens.
The results indicate that CSD may be used as an animal model for anhedonia.
Anhedonia is one of the most significant symptoms of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), affecting approximately 20% of patients worldwide.
It refers to the loss or reduction of pleasure experienced by an individual, leading to an inability to enjoy pleasurable events.

In addition to major depressive disorder (MDD), anhedonia has also been described in other mental disorders, such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, eating disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder.
However, despite being considered a core feature of several psychological disorders, there is still no consensus on how to assess it.
The lack of standardized evaluation methods makes it difficult to compare results across studies.
Therefore, new methods have emerged aimed at improving the diagnosis and treatment of anhedonia.
The main challenge related to the research on the absence of pleasure is the inability to measure it directly.
On the contrary, researchers use indirect measurement methods based on behavioral tests.
For example, sucrose consumption tests, forced swimming tests, and open field tests are commonly used to assess pleasure.
Despite the fact that these tests provide valuable information related to the absence of pleasure, they do not enable us to understand the neural circuits involved.
Therefore, it is necessary to conduct further research using more complex techniques.

Introduction: Exact solutions play an important role in theoretical physics as they allow us to compare and test various physical ideas against concrete predictions.

The purpose of this study is to develop an improved model to simulate the diffusion process within biological cells, particularly the diffusion processes occurring at the nuclear membrane and its associated structures.

The proposed method involves coupling two existing models; one model uses Brownian dynamics simulations to describe the movement of molecules in the cytoplasm (the fluid part of the cell), while the other model represents the nucleus as a porous medium containing stationary obstacles.
The components of the latter were developed by considering the geometry of the nuclear pore complex network, which consists of cylindrical pores connected by narrower passages.

We consider the capacity region of a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) fading channel, where each transmitter has perfect knowledge of its own instantaneous channel state information and uses a quantized precoding matrix to maximize the mutual information between itself and the receiver.

We prove that for any given number of transmitting antennas for all transmitters, there exists an optimal number of receiving antennas such that when all receivers have the same number of antennas, the total capacity is maximized.
This result still holds when the channels are correlated in time or frequency.
The optimal number of receiving antennas increases as the transmitter uses more transmitting antennas.

For example, we found that when each user uses three receiving antennas, using four transmitting antennas yields the highest total transmission rate; however, if there are eight transmitting antennas available, five receiving antennas should be used.

Introduction  
Recently, an increasing number of studies have utilized network theory (Watts & Strogatz 1998, Newman 2003a) to investigate various aspects of language structure (Ferrer-i-Cancho 2004, Ferrer-i-Cancho et al. 2005).
These studies mainly focus on phonological systems (e.g., Ferrer-i-Cancho 2002, Ferrer-i-Cancho and Solé 2007) or lexical-semantic relationships (e.g., Steyvers & Tenenbaum 2005).

However, there is also a growing interest in exploring other levels of language, such as morphology-syntax (Ferrer-i-Canchos 2006), prosody (Ferrer-i-Canchós 2008), pragmatics (Ferrer-i-Canchis 2009), and even discourse (Ferrer-i-Canchi 2010).
This article focuses on a specific aspect of syntax—namely word order—and uses network analysis to explore its structural characteristics.
More specifically, we can use network theory to analyze the data collected through corpus linguistics methods.
We believe that this type of research may provide new insights into how syntactic structures emerge during language acquisition.

We provided the newly measured rotational width (W20) and surface brightness (SB), which are derived from a galaxy sample with an inclination angle between 30° and 80° from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 7.
We found that W20 has a strong correlation with SB at a fixed luminosity, but its correlation with galaxy mass is either weak or nonexistent.
This correlation still exists when we limit our analysis to late-type spiral galaxies known to have flat rotation curves.

These results indicate that the scatter observed in the Tully-Fisher relationship may be primarily due to variations in surface brightness among galaxies with similar luminosities, rather than differences in their masses.
In addition, we indicate that this effect can explain why previous studies have found no significant dependency of the TF relationship on the angle of inclination.
Finally, we demonstrate how these correlations affect the estimation of the Hubble constant obtained using TF relations.
Our research findings also provide an explanation for the significant differences in values obtained by different authors when selecting samples with varying ranges of inclination angles.

We present the results of an extensive study that involves gas dynamics, star formation activity, dust extinction, stellar populations, and the black hole accretion characteristics in the strong lensing galaxy (A1689-zD1) at redshift 3.07.
The lens magnification factor is approximately 30 ± 5.
We use deep near-infrared spectroscopy to measure the kinematics of molecular hydrogen emission lines with high spatial resolution.
Our observations indicate that this system is composed of two merging galaxies that are 1 kpc apart in the line of sight direction.
One of the components shows strong Hβ emission, indicating the presence of an active galactic nucleus (AGN).
The mass of the active galactic nucleus component is approximately \(10^9 M_{\text{sol}}\), equivalent to a supermassive black hole with a mass of about \(1 \times 10^8 M_{\text{sol}}\).
Through our spatially resolved measurements, we have found evidence of strong nuclear starbursts on scales as small as 100 parsecs.

We used three-dimensional fluid dynamics simulations to investigate the gravitational instability of two different self-gravitating disks with varying rotation rates under the presence and absence of a magnetic field.

We found that, regardless of the circumstances, intense gravitational instability (GI) can occur at large radii, but it is suppressed under the influence of a strong magnetic field near the central star.
The disk mass required to trigger gravitational instability decreases with increasing radius because the Tomerle Q parameter becomes smaller due to the weakening stellar gravity.
In the absence of a magnetic field, we also studied how the initial density distribution affects the growth rate of gravitational instability.
Our results indicate that the growth time scale depends on the radial distribution of surface density.
In addition, we also studied whether GI would lead to fragmentation.
Fragmentation only occurs when the initial surface density gradient on the disk is steep.
Finally, we discussed the possible implications of our findings on planetary formation.

Gravitational instability (GI) can lead to the formation of spiral arms in gravitationally bound systems, such as galaxies, which can play an important role in various astrophysical phenomena, including planet formation.

However, it is currently unclear whether gravitational instability plays a role in the protoplanetary disks around young stars, as these disks are magnetized and their rotational characteristics are also quite complex.
Here, we conduct three-dimensional fluid dynamics simulations to investigate this issue.

We investigated droplet excitations in a two-dimensional spin glass model with nearest-neighbor interactions and random ferromagnetic bonds, which is known to have an infinite number of metastable states at zero temperature.

We demonstrate that the system has two different types of droplets: small droplets similar to those found in other models studied previously; and large droplets that exhibit characteristics of their fractal structure.
The latter can be considered an extension of the droplet model previously proposed for the three-dimensional Ising glass.
Additionally, we found another type of excitation - the so-called "giant droplets" - which do not exist in any of these systems.
These huge droplets are the reason for the non-universal behavior observed numerically near the critical point.
Finally, we believe that our results provide strong numerical support for the existence of a new phase transition line, specifically from the paramagnetic state to the spin glass state.

The Kuiper Belt is the source region for most short-period comets, but its formation is still not very clear.
We present results from N-body simulations that show how collisions between planetesimals in the region of Neptune's assembly can produce bodies with orbits similar to those observed today.
The initial conditions are based on planetary migration models, in which Neptune migrated outward by about 30 astronomical units and was then halted at its current position.
Our calculations indicate that the Kuiper Belt was formed due to collisional erosion between bodies similar in size to Pluto (with a radius of about 1000 kilometers).
This process produced a group of small bodies with orbital eccentricities of up to 0.3.
The subsequent encounter with Neptune caused some of these celestial bodies to be scattered into highly eccentric orbits.
These results provide an explanation for why there seems to be no correlation between the size distribution of KBOs and their orbital eccentricity.

Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is an important evolutionary force that can increase genetic diversity and accelerate evolution, but it also has negative effects, such as disrupting co-adapted gene complexes or introducing deleterious mutations into the recipient genome.
Through this study, we investigated how horizontal gene transfer (HGT) affects the average fitness of single cells evolving under different environmental conditions, using computational models.
We found that when cells are exposed to fluctuating environments with high levels of stress events, horizontal gene transfer (HGT) increases the average fitness.
However, if there are only slight fluctuations, horizontal gene transfer will lower the average fitness because it introduces detrimental mutations.
Finally, in a constant environment without any external pressure, horizontal gene transfer will not have any effect on the average fitness.

Our research findings indicate that horizontal gene transfer may have played an important role in the early stages of life's evolution by enhancing organisms' ability to adapt to environmental changes.
Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) occurs in organisms that share similar DNA sequences and is one of the most significant evolutionary forces known today [1].
This allows for the rapid acquisition of new genes, which helps to increase genetic diversity within species.

We present the results of the anisotropic analysis of the distribution of satellite galaxies around isolated field galaxies, using data obtained from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).
We found that there is no significant difference between the distribution of satellite galaxies of different brightness or colors and the distribution of satellite galaxies around the central galaxy.
The observed anisotropy is consistent with the predictions based on the tidal forces during galaxy mergers.
This indicates that these effects may be responsible for the formation of galaxy clusters and groups.

1 Introduction  
Galaxy clusters contain thousands of galaxies, which exist within a shared dark matter halo.
These systems are formed by gravitational collapse caused by the mutual attraction of the galaxies that compose them.
However, it remains unclear how this process occurs on the timescale from the interaction of individual galaxies to the formation of large galaxy clusters that contain hundreds of member galaxies.
In particular, we do not know whether all galaxies will evolve into members of large star clusters, or whether some will always remain isolated field galaxies throughout the history of the universe.

We report the fabrication and characterization of charge qubits based on self-assembled InAs quantum dots (QDs) embedded in GaAs/AlGaAs heterostructures.
We demonstrated that by using an optimized growth process, we can obtain high-quality quantum dot layers with low defect density, which is crucial for achieving good coherence times.
The sample was grown by molecular beam epitaxy under arsenic-rich conditions at 600°C to minimize the formation of screw dislocations.
After annealing at 650 °C for 10 seconds, a self-assembled InAs/GaAs quantum dot layer was formed, followed by the deposition of a 50 nm thick Al0.3Ga0.7As barrier layer.
Finally, a 20-nanometer thick GaAs encapsulation layer was deposited.
The sample structure is displayed in a schematic form in Figure 1.

The photoluminescence spectrum shows an emission peak at approximately 1280 nanometers, corresponding to the ground state exciton transition of single quantum dots, as well as higher energy states associated with charged excitons.
We proposed an algorithm that uses images as the basis for constructing a hierarchical grid space index.

The algorithm is based on the observation that many real-world datasets can naturally be represented as images and can be combined with existing techniques (such as R-trees or quadtrees) to improve performance.

We conducted experiments on synthetic datasets generated from different distributions (uniform, normal, exponential) to demonstrate the performance comparison of our method with other methods. The size of the datasets ranged from 1K to 100 million points.
Our results show that there is a significant improvement in query response time compared to traditional methods.
In this work, we propose a new spatial indexing construction method that uses image processing algorithms to extract information about the dataset being indexed.
This information was then used to establish a grid hierarchy, with the leaf nodes containing pointers to various objects in the dataset.
These grids provide efficient access to all objects within them while also allowing for quick queries across multiple grids.

We propose a method for causal inference in longitudinal data based on Marginal Structural Models (MSMs), which is limited by the history of past treatments and covariates. We refer to it as "historically restricted" MSMs.
We demonstrate how these models can be used to estimate the average effect during periods without treatment applied or when outcomes are unobserved.

Our proposed method is illustrated through two examples involving missing data: one example has no unobserved confounding factors, but the outcome information for certain subjects is incomplete; the other example has both incomplete outcome information and unmeasured confounding factors affecting the estimates.
The first example indicates that the estimates provided by our proposed method are similar to those obtained under complete follow-up when all relevant variables have been measured.
On the contrary, the second example illustrates a situation where the standard method may lead to biased results due to incomplete outcome information or unmeasured confounding factors.
In conclusion, we provided simulation evidence indicating that our proposed method still performs well even when the underlying model assumptions are not completely satisfied.
Keywords: marginal structural model, longitudinal data analysis
The information-based asset pricing model is an extension of the traditional Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM), which incorporates additional factors in its analysis.
The first factor, the market risk premium, represents the additional return that investors require from holding riskier assets compared to low-risk investments (such as treasury bills or bonds).
The second factor, namely scale effect, reflects the difference in expected returns between small-cap stocks and large-cap stocks.

The third factor, the value effect, measures the return difference between stocks with high book-to-market ratios and those with low book-to-market ratios; this factor becomes particularly important during periods of declining interest rates.
This article briefly outlines these three factors and provides examples of how they affect investment decisions.
The Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) was developed by Sharpe (1964), Lintner (1965), Mossin (1966), and Black (1972), and it is one of the most widely used models in the field of finance today.

It points out that the expected return on any specific security should be equal to the sum of two parts: the risk-free rate plus the risk premium related to the inherent level of systemic risk of each security.

In other words, if your portfolio only includes risk-free securities, your expected return will simply be equal to the risk-free rate; however, if you have a diversified portfolio that includes both risky and risk-free securities, your expected return will increase proportionally with the amount of risk you take on.
For example, let's assume we have a hypothetical investor who holds a portfolio consisting of 50% U.S. Treasury bonds and 50% in a S&P 500 index fund.

We use hydrodynamic simulations to study how protoclusters grow and evolve from galaxy clusters, with a focus on their baryonic components at high redshifts (z > 5).
We found that by z = 3, most of these regions are highly ionized due to photon heating from the ultraviolet background radiation.
The resulting low abundance of neutral hydrogen leads to a lower density of absorbing materials along the line of sight toward such objects compared to observations at lower redshifts.
This effect is more pronounced in high-quality halos, as their gas fraction is larger than that of low-quality halos.
Using this result, we derive constraints on the abundance of high-redshift proto-clusters in relation to halo mass.
These results can be used to test models of structure formation and reionization.
In addition, they provided useful input parameters for future studies of cluster-scale relations using weak lensing technology.
Keywords: hydrogen ionization state, galaxy cluster, reionization
We report on the detection and analysis of the optical shock front in the supernova remnant (SNR) Tycho using data obtained from the Subaru High-Resolution Spectrograph (HDS).

The observed spectrum in the wavelength range of 3200 Å to 9400 Å shows strong emission lines from hydrogen, helium, nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur, argon, calcium, magnesium, silicon, and iron ions. We found that the characteristics of these emission lines can be well reproduced by a model consisting of two components; one is a photoionized plasma component that emits forbidden lines such as [O III] λλ4959, 5007 and [S II] λλ6716, 6731, while the other is a collisional ionized plasma component that produces significant Balmer series lines, including Hα.
Based on this result, we conclude that the detected shock front is primarily dominated by collisional ionization, rather than photoionization.
Keywords: Supernova Remnants
We present the calculated results for the two-photon transition rates between the excited states of atomic hydrogen, including all relevant bound-bound and bound-free processes.
We use these results to calculate the evolution of the neutral hydrogen atom number density during the reionization process of the universe.
The main goal is to study how this process depends on the properties of the first stars that ionized the universe.
We are particularly interested in the impact of different initial mass functions (IMF) of stars on the ionization history of the universe.
For example, if the number of high-mass stars exceeds that of low-mass stars, they may produce more photons per unit time, which could lead to faster reionization.

On the other hand, if most of the energy released by the first star is converted into winds or supernova explosions rather than radiation, then the number of ultraviolet photons produced will be reduced, leading to a slower rate of reionization.
Our calculations show that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has only a small impact on the overall duration of reionization, but it does affect its detailed shape.

We report the discovery and study of the intraday variable (IDV) radio quasar J1128+592 at redshift z = 1.8.
The object was discovered while searching for new variable intermittent stars in data obtained from the Very Large Array (VLA).
We monitored the source over two time periods separated by one year in order to observe its variability on time scales ranging from 10 minutes to several days.
Our results indicate that this is a strong internal variable source, with a peak-to-peak amplitude that varies by up to 50% on time scales as short as 20 minutes.
This makes J1128+592 one of the fastest-changing quasars known to date.
In addition, we found evidence of long-term changes on a timescale of over 100 days.
These may be caused by interstellar scintillation resulting from density fluctuations in the line of sight towards the source.
Finally, we present the spectrum obtained using the Keck Telescope, which shows the characteristic broad emission lines typical of quasars.
The output flow of the bound neurons is modeled using autoregressive models and feedback mechanisms, which can be used to predict the future states of the system.
The proposed method has been used to predict traffic flow on highway networks.
Based on this research, we propose a new method for modeling the output flow of binding neurons (BNs) that is based on autoregressive models and feedback mechanisms.
We use Bayesian networks as a fundamental component of our prediction framework, which can learn the temporal dependencies between input streams and generate predictions about their future states.
Our experimental results indicate that the proposed method outperforms other methods, such as ARIMA and LSTM, in short-term traffic prediction tasks.

We analyzed the evolution of interstellar dust particles, based on the particle size distribution inferred from infrared observations conducted with ISO (Infrared Space Observatory).
We found that since the formation of the Sun, grain growth has mainly been influenced by polymerization.
During this time frame, the total mass density of dust has increased by about an order of magnitude.
This increase can be explained by the aggregation of gaseous metals on previously existing particles or by the condensation of new material from the gas phase.
In addition to these processes, we also consider the fragmentation and breaking caused by collisions between particles.
During the condensation process of small particles, fragmentation dominates, but its importance diminishes when the particle size exceeds 0.1 micrometers.
In large particles, fragmentation leads to a decrease in number density, which counteracts the effects of aggregation.
Our results are consistent with previous studies that used different methods.

We investigated the main aerosol processes in the atmosphere under severe air pollution conditions caused by human emissions, using the remote sensing and chemical analysis data collected from Kashiwa City, Chiba Prefecture, Japan, between September 2009 and March 2010.

The results indicate that sulfate particles are primarily generated through the homogeneous nucleation process from gas to particle under days of low relative humidity (RH); however, when the relative humidity is above 80%, they can also form as secondary organic aerosols (SOA).
On certain pollution days, secondary organic aerosols (SOAs) account for more than 50% of the total submicron particulate matter mass concentration.
In addition to these two main sources, aged sea salt particles also make a significant contribution to the PM2.5 mass concentration levels.
We found that throughout the research period, the formation of SOA occurred very frequently due to the persistent stable meteorological conditions.

These findings suggest that to accurately assess the characteristics of atmospheric aerosols and their impact on human health, we should consider both primary and secondary aerosol production simultaneously.
Keywords: aerosol processes, remote sensing, chemical composition

The Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) is an evolutionary stage during which stars lose a significant amount of mass and are responsible for the production of most of the dust in galaxies.
The exact mechanism of this process is still unclear; however, it has been suggested that pulsations play a key role in it.

In this work, we present new observations of two well-developed intermediate-mass stars with very different pulsation characteristics in order to study how their pulsation behavior affects their mass loss rates.
We found that stars with higher pulsation amplitudes lose more material than their counterparts with lower pulsation amplitudes.
This indicates that a high amplitude may be needed during the AGB phase to drive significant mass loss.
However, our results also indicate that there seems to be no significant relationship between the pulsation cycle or pattern and the mass loss rate.
These findings are important for understanding the evolution of low metallicity stars and the formation of planetary nebulae.

We present deep optical imaging of the dwarf irregular galaxy IC 1613 in the B, V, Rc, and Ic bands, obtained using the Wide Field Imager (WFI) on the MPG/ESO 2.2-meter telescope at the La Silla Observatory.
The data are reduced using the standard IRAF procedures.
We applied aperture corrections to the photometry using the fitting of the point spread function, resulting in the total luminosity at an aperture radius of 5 arcseconds.
Our results were compared with previous studies based on shallower observations.
By using addition, we derived a new estimate of the distance modulus DM = 27.9 ± 0.1 magnitudes and the foreground extinction AV = 0.10 ± 0.02 magnitudes for this galaxy.
According to our photometric measurements, combined with these values, we determined the absolute magnitudes: M_B = -15.6 ± 0.3 magnitudes, M_V = -14.7 ± 0.4 magnitudes.

We have launched the first version of our new code WHAM (Weighted Hybrid Arbitrary Mesh), which is based on the recently developed Weighted Essentially Non-Oscillatory (WENO) scheme for solving one-dimensional and multidimensional hyperbolic conservation laws.
The main idea of this method is to combine higher-order spatial reconstruction with adaptive mesh refinement technology to achieve high precision at low computational cost.
We have implemented multiple different versions of the WENO algorithm in the code, including the fifth-order WENO-Z scheme and the third-order and fifth-order WENO-JS schemes.

To supplement this, we have also implemented a fourth-order Runge-Kutta time integration scheme, as well as the Harten-Lax-van Leer contact discontinuity capture scheme, to handle discontinuities that arise during the hydrodynamic evolution process.
Our results show that these algorithms can produce accurate solutions when compared with exact solutions or reference solutions.
We propose that a plasma water pit is an analogy model for perturbative black holes in quantum gravity, and we demonstrate how to use this model to calculate Hawking radiation.
We consider a system consisting of two parallel plates that are separated by a distance L, with a dielectric material in between.
These electrodes are connected to a voltage source, causing current to flow through the dielectric medium.
This is due to the formation of a plasma water pit on one electrode.

To study the properties of these plasma droplets, we adopt a fluid description in which charged carriers are treated as particles moving under the influence of the electric field generated by their own motion.
Using this method, we found that there exists a critical voltage value \( V_c \). When the applied voltage exceeds this value, the plasma reservoir becomes unstable to disturbances.
At a voltage greater than Vc, the plasma water pool collapses into a point-like object known as a "plasma sphere."
Social tagging is an emerging technology that allows users to annotate resources using keywords or tags, which other users can utilize during the search and discovery process.
Based on this work, we propose a novel approach to leverage social annotation information for automatic resource discovery.
We will first introduce the concept of label semantic similarity based on the WordNet ontology.

Then, using the proposed semantic similarity measure and user personal information, we developed two algorithms: (i) TagRank and (ii) UserTagRank, to rank the importance of each tag related to a given resource.
Finally, we conducted experiments on a real dataset collected from the Delicious website to evaluate our method.
The experimental results show that TagRank and UserTagRank can significantly improve the performance of the existing state-of-the-art techniques.
Keywords: Semantic Web, social tagging, resource discovery, ranking algorithms.

We study the distortions caused by two groups of diffeomorphisms, one group acting on circles and the other group acting on bounded surfaces.

We prove that if the first group is generated by an irrational rotation number, then there exists a sequence of elements in the second group that converges to the first group at an exponential rate (with respect to its Leibniz constant).
This result can be viewed as a generalization of the classical Denjoy theorem for circular homotopy mappings.
The proof employs techniques recently developed from geometric measure theory, such as the integrability properties of measures that are invariant under surface diffeomorphisms.
We specifically utilized the results of David Gabai, Richard Hamilton, and Michael Hutchings.

We analyzed users' attention to tags and resources in the collaborative tagging community, based on data collected from Delicious.com over a period of three years (2005-2007).

The theory that the universe underwent a phase of rapid expansion in its early days is now widely accepted by cosmologists as a possible explanation for many observed features of today's universe, such as its flatness and uniformity.
In this presentation, I will discuss how the ideas of string theory are used to construct inflationary models that are consistent with current observational results.
The basic idea behind these structures is that they involve the motion of strings and membranes in extra spacetime dimensions.
These membranes can come closer together or move further apart depending on their initial conditions.
If two membranes collide, it will cause a rapid expansion of spacetime known as "inflation."
This process will continue, and as the membranes separate again, the universe will return to its original size.
In addition to discussing some of the latest achievements obtained using these technologies, I will also describe some open questions related to them.
Finally, I will briefly mention another approach to constructing a realistic inflation model based on the so-called "brane world scenario."

We present the results of an optical monitoring campaign on two bright quasars with redshifts of z = 1.7 and 2.1, aimed at studying their long-term spectral line and continuum variability characteristics.
The observation was conducted from September 2005 to December 2007 using the Nordic Optical Telescope (NOT) equipped with ALFOSC.
We found that these two objects show significant changes over a time range of several months to several years.
We specifically detected significant changes in the profile of the Hβ emission line, which occurred alongside fluctuations in the flux density of the adjacent continuous spectrum regions.
These findings suggest that the observed spectral changes can be explained as a variable obscuration effect caused by the movement of clouds between us and the central engine.
This situation is supported because the detected changes seem to occur simultaneously in all three Balmer lines that we studied.
In addition, we found evidence indicating the occurrence of additional short-term fluctuation events within a single night.

We study the global polarization of the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) produced in non-central heavy ion collisions using an effective chiral model, which includes vector mesons, axial-vector mesons, as well as quarks and antiquarks.
We found that the global polarization is primarily determined by the initial angular momentum carried by the colliding nuclei, which can be estimated using the Glauber model.
As the collision energy increases, the amplitude of global polarization rapidly decreases due to the increasing number of particles participating in the reaction.
Our results show that global polarization at RHIC energy could reach about 10%, but if the energy is increased to LHC levels, the polarization will significantly decrease.

Introduction

Research has found that at RHIC energy, global polarization can reach about 20% [4], while at LHC energy, the polarization will drop to less than 1% [5].
This phenomenon is closely related to the initial angular momentum carried by the colliding nuclei; therefore, it provides us with a new way to probe nuclear structure.

We study the confounding complexity of planar graphs, which is defined as the minimum number of edges that need to be removed in order to make it impossible for an opponent to distinguish between two isomorphic copies of the graph.

We indicate that this problem can be solved by solving a linear programming problem with O(n) variables and constraints (where n represents the number of vertices), or equivalently, by finding the maximum matching in a bipartite graph.
This produces a polynomial-time algorithm for calculating obfuscation complexity.
In a theorem, we obtained a lower bound for the confusion complexity of any n-dimensional tree T.
Finally, we prove that there exist infinitely many trees whose confusion complexity is equal to the number of their leaves.

Based on this work, we propose an energy-efficient cooperative transmission scheme for wireless sensor networks (WSNs).
The proposed scheme is based on combining cooperative beamforming at the source node with cooperative transmission to multiple relay nodes to improve lifetime performance.
Specifically, the source node first sends packets using its maximum power level.
Then, if the data packets are not successfully received within a certain period of time, it will switch to a lower power level.
If one or more packets are successfully decoded, the source node will reset its transmission power to the previous value.
We derived closed-form expressions for the outage probability and average throughput under Rayleigh fading channels.
Our results indicate that, compared to traditional solutions, the approach we proposed can significantly extend the lifespan of the network while not affecting the reliability of the system.
Finally, numerical examples are provided to validate the theoretical analysis.
Keywords: lifespan improvement; relay selection; energy efficiency; failure probability.

We present the results of our analysis of BATSE gamma-ray burst (GRB) data. We used three different statistical methods to search for evidence that there are at least two distinct populations in the distribution of GRB durations, as previously suggested by other authors.

We did not find any single method that could provide such strong evidence for the bimodal distribution; however, when the three methods are used in combination, the evidence supporting this hypothesis is very strong.
The differences in the optimal parameters obtained separately by each method are significant, suggesting that the underlying true distribution may be more complex than previously thought.

In particular, our results indicate that events with the shortest durations form a distinct class of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), which have characteristics that are significantly different from those of gamma-ray bursts with longer durations.
This result is of great significance for understanding the nature of these phenomena and for planning future tasks that specifically study them.
Keywords: Gamma-ray bursts, statistical analysis.

The propagation model describes how cosmic rays propagate in space through a diffusion process, while also experiencing energy loss due to ionization and Coulomb scattering with interstellar gas particles.
This article provides an overview of cosmic ray physics and introduces some basic concepts to help understand cosmic ray propagation models.
Cosmic rays have been observed since the 19th century.
They are primarily composed of protons (about 85%) and helium nuclei (about 14%).
Their energy range reaches 10^20 electron volts.
However, their source remains unclear.
Someone suggested that they may come from explosions of stars known as supernovae or from active galactic nuclei, such as quasars.
In this case, they will travel through interstellar space before reaching Earth.
Another possibility is that they are accelerated within our own galaxy.
If not, they can contact us directly from afar.
In this work, we propose an algorithm for analyzing and comparing hidden Markov models (HMMs) of profiles.
The proposed method is based on the concept of the Structural Similarity Index Measurement (SSIM), which has been widely used in image processing to measure the similarity between two images.
We use the Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) as a metric to compare the similarity between Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) by measuring their similarity at different levels of granularity.
In addition, our method allows us to identify the regions responsible for the differences between the models.

We present new observational results from the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) on the two internal network sunspots in active region NOAA AR 12192, taken on May 24 and 25, 2013.
The first sunspot was observed for about three hours, during which it rotated more than 90 degrees.
We found that this sunspot is composed of magnetic flux tubes oriented in different directions.
In addition to these features, we also observed an extended bright region between the main sunspot's dark areas.
The feature was previously reported as penumbral filaments, but our data does not show any evidence of such structures.
On the contrary, we interpret this feature as a coronal rain cluster.
The second sunspot was only observed for 1 hour before being blocked by the Earth's atmosphere.
During this observation period, the sunspot rotated less than 30 degrees.
Our analysis shows that there is a dark band surrounding both of these sunspots, which may be related to the moat surrounding the larger sunspot.

We present new photometric measurement data of the globular cluster NGC 1904 obtained using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) on the Hubble Space Telescope, with four filters covering optical and near-infrared wavelength ranges.
We found that this star cluster has an extended blue horizontal branch (BHB), which contains both hot blue horizontal branch stars (BHBs) and blue stragglers (BSs).
To study these groups separately, we used two different methods.
First, we select stars based on their position on the Red Giant Branch (RGB); secondly, we use our best-fit model CMD as input for artificial star tests.
The two methods yielded consistent results.
Our analysis shows that the proportion of blue supergiants among all evolved stars is f = 0.11 ± 0.01.
This value is very consistent with previous research findings on other star clusters.

Introduction  
In recent years, the discovery of several giant exoplanets has revealed that their orbital periods are shorter than four days.

These short-period planets are particularly interesting because they may be tidally locked and rotate in sync with their axes, which would result in a strong contrast between day and night on their surfaces.
In addition, the atmospheres of these planets may experience extreme conditions due to high temperatures and intense radiation fields.
Therefore, understanding the reactions of planetary atmospheres in these situations may provide important insights into processes in our solar system and other planetary systems.
Here, we present the discovery and preliminary characterization of TrES-3b; it is a hot Jupiter discovered through the transit method, with an orbital period of P = 3.09 days.

Using follow-up observations with the Spitzer Space Telescope, we demonstrate that TrES-3b orbits its parent star close enough that tidal forces are expected to synchronize the planet's rotation axis with its orbital angular momentum vector.

However, we did not detect any significant infrared excess radiation associated with the planet itself or its host star, which indicates that either there is not a substantial amount of dust material around the planet, or the temperature of the planet is too low to produce detectable thermal radiation above 4 microns.
We present new results on the dust extinction properties in external galaxies, based on HST/ACS observations of Type Ia supernovae (SNe) in the redshift range of z = 0.1-0.7.

We found that Type Ia supernovae are systematically bluer than expected if they were standard candles, but this phenomenon is consistent with dust extinction by interstellar matter along the line of sight.
Through addition, we find evidence of an additional dust extinction component, which increases rapidly at higher redshifts.
This additional extinction may be related to the interstellar medium surrounding galaxy clusters, or it may be caused by recent star formation activity occurring within individual galaxies.
These findings are of great significance for cosmological studies that use distant Type Ia supernovae as distance indicators.

We propose another derivation method for Einstein's gravity that does not use the axiom of choice, based on the concept that topology can be hidden within general relativity (GR).

We report simultaneous observations in the X-ray and radio bands conducted using Chandra, RXTE/PCA, Swift/XRT, and ATCA during the outburst of the transient magnetar XTE J 1810-197.
The source has been detected at all wavelengths, except for the optical wavelengths.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) is the largest provider of biomedical research funding in the United States, but it also supports non-biomedical research through its external funding programs.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) has funded thousands of scientists at hundreds of institutions nationwide to conduct basic scientific research that may have significant applications beyond medicine.

This study examines how researchers utilize their NIH funding for non-biomedical projects by analyzing data collected from interviews conducted with NIH-funded researchers. These interviews are part of an ongoing longitudinal survey of NIH-funded researchers.
We found that many of these scientists primarily or exclusively use their NIH funding for research activities unrelated to biomedicine, such as teaching, administrative, and service work.
However, we also found that some scientists receiving NIH funding for non-medical related research still spend most of their time engaged in medical-related research.
Additionally, our results indicate that scientists' perceptions of spending more time on biomedical research compared to non-biomedical research do not always align with their actual behavior.

We present the broadband (from radio to X-rays) observational results of gamma-ray burst 061121, which is one of the most powerful gamma-ray bursts detected by Swift/BAT, with an isotropic energy release of 1.8 x 10^54 erg in the 15-350 keV band.
The temporal behavior of this event is very complex; it consists of multiple pulses that overlap during the instantaneous emission phase and the early part of the afterglow.
We found two different components in the optical light curve - one that initially decays quickly, but then stabilizes within a time range of 0.1 to 10 days after the outburst.
This gradual flattening phenomenon may be caused by the ongoing activity of the central engine or the re-generated shocks.

We use molecular dynamics simulations to study the vibrational density of states (VDOS) of glass materials, taking into account the non-harmonic interactions between particles.

We indicate that the vibrational density of states (VDOS) can be decomposed into three main contributions: one corresponds to phonons in the low frequency range; another contribution is concentrated around the Debye frequency, associated with optical phonons; and the final contribution is in the high frequency range, originating from the presence of unstable modes.
The latter is responsible for the emergence of the so-called Bose peak in the phonon density of states.
In addition, we found that these unstable patterns have a strong tendency to form clusters or groups of correlated particles.
Finally, by analyzing the spatial distribution of unstable modes, it is evident that they tend to localize near areas with structural defects, such as structures styled like a dodecahedron.

This localization effect has led us to propose a simple model based on the existence of two different types of sites within the material: one is stable sites, characterized by their ability to support vibrations over a wide energy range; the other is unstable sites, which only allow for small amplitude oscillations.

We report the discovery of a new isolated neutron star (INS) candidate, PSR J1852+0040, using data collected from the Parkes Radio Telescope and the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) in the Southern Hemisphere.
The pulsar was discovered while searching for millisecond pulsars with high proper motion.
Its rotation period is P = 1.4 milliseconds, located at a distance of D = 3 kiloparsecs.

We proposed an analytical method for detecting solar neutrinos using a combination of a radioactive source and a germanium detector, based on Bayesian statistical methods.

The method takes into account all relevant experimental uncertainties, including those related to background subtraction, as well as time-varying systematic effects such as changes in energy calibration or detector efficiency.

We find no significant difference in the proportion of active galactic nuclei (AGN) in red and blue galaxies, but we do observe an excess of AGN in normal galaxies of intermediate colors.

This indicates that, contrary to previous ideas, active galactic nuclei (AGNs) are not preferentially distributed in red or blue galaxies; rather, they appear to be more common in galaxies of intermediate color.

We have presented a new exact solution for the Einstein field equations in static axisymmetric spacetimes with two conjugate Killing vectors. These solutions are generated by applying nonholonomic frame transformations (NFT) to known vacuum solutions.
This NFT is constructed based on the assumption of a metric coefficient derived from an arbitrary function that relies solely on radial coordinates.
We demonstrate how to generate a family of black hole solutions with different horizon topologies using this method.
We have particularly discovered a new rotating black ring solution with a toroidal event horizon.
These solutions were previously obtained as limits of static black rings, but our method allows us to obtain them directly without any additional assumptions or approximations.
Finally, we discuss some open questions related to these results.

The study of exact solutions to the Einstein equations has played a key role in understanding many aspects of general relativity.
However, constructing such solutions is often difficult because they require solving complex nonlinear partial differential equations.
Considering situations involving rotation and/or material fields, among other physically interesting cases, this problem becomes more challenging.
However, there are various techniques that can generate new classes of solutions starting from simpler solutions.
One of the most powerful methods involves transforming the original solution into another solution through a so-called non-conservative framework transformation. [1]
This transformation retains certain geometric properties of spacetime while changing other properties; see [2] -

Static axisymmetric spacetime plays an important role in astrophysics, as it describes the external gravitational fields of rotating objects such as stars, planets, and black holes.

We proposed an improved abundance measurement for the black hole binary nova Sco X-1, based on high-resolution spectral data obtained with UVES at VLT-UT2 in November 2004 and January 2005.

We present new results on the occurrence and properties of interferometric absorbers along the line of sight to GRB 080913, based on high-resolution spectra obtained with X-shooter on VLT-UT2 (ESO project ID 080.A-9007).

We detected two strong absorption systems in this outburst spectrum, one associated with an intervening galaxy at a redshift of z = 1.5394 ± 0.0002, and the other at z = 2.084 ± 0.001, likely caused by a damping Lyα absorber.
The latter was detected by Fynbo et al. (2009) using low-resolution spectra taken with FORS-2/VLT.

We reported on the infrared (IR) spectroscopic study of the formation and evolution of formic acid (HCOOH) in ice under simulated astrophysical conditions.
The experiment was conducted under vacuum ultraviolet radiation at 10 K, exposing a mixture of pure water or H2O and CH3OH for up to 100 hours.
The infrared spectrum shows that the amount of HCOOH increases with the increase in irradiation time.
We also found evidence of the presence of other species, such as CO2, CO, CH4, NH3, H2S, SO2, and OCS.

Formic acid is one of the most abundant organic molecules in the universe.

We present here a laboratory study on the formation pathways of formic acid in cold environments using infrared spectroscopy.
We describe an infrared cloud monitor that has been developed to detect cloud layers located above the Mauna Kea Observatory in Hawaii.
The system uses two near-infrared cameras and is designed to operate continuously at night during astronomical observations.
It provides information about the sky conditions across the entire field of view (FOV) of the telescope's main mirror.
This information can be used by observers to select targets or adjust their observation strategies accordingly.
We present the results obtained after installing the instrument in August 2005.
These data indicate that atmospheric transparency varies significantly within the field of view (FOV) of the telescope.

As an example, we found that the median value of the total integrated water vapor column density measured within one hour after each observation is 0.5 mm H2O for the northern field of view and 1.1 mm H2O for the southern field of view.
We also demonstrated how these measurements help us optimize our observation strategies.

The minimal supersymmetric standard model (nuMSM) is an extension of the standard model that includes three right-handed neutrinos and an additional Higgs doublet, capable of simultaneously explaining all known phenomena in particle physics.
In this model, there are two new particles — the neutral leptons N_1 and N_2, which have not yet been observed in experiments.

We considered the processes of producing neutralinos through the Drell-Yan mechanism, as well as the process of producing a single neutralino via s-channel W boson exchange or t-channel photon/neutralino exchange.

In this work, we consider the problem of optimizing the performance of multi-hop wireless mesh networks (WMNs), where each node is equipped with multiple antennas and communicates with its neighbors using a vector broadcast channel.
We proposed an algorithm that jointly optimizes the routing tree at the network layer and the beamforming vectors at the physical layer to support unicast and multicast traffic.

The author studied the growth rates and fluctuations of different types of human cancer cells grown under controlled conditions, using an automatic image analysis system to measure their size changes over time.

This indicates that the observed phenotypic diversity may reflect the genetic or epigenetic variation present in the original parent population.

Spin echo is observed when a spin system is subjected to two consecutive radio frequency (RF) pulses, with the interval between these two pulses referred to as the pulse separation time Tsep.

The first radio frequency pulse generates a macroscopic magnetization vector M0, which precesses around the external magnetic field Bext at the Larmor frequency fL = γBext, where γ is the gyromagnetic ratio of the nuclear spin.

After the second radio frequency pulse (with a flip angle of θ2 and a phase shift φ2 relative to the first pulse), the transverse component of the magnetization vector M2(t) exhibits exponential decay due to the dephasing effects caused by the local magnetic fields generated by adjacent nuclei.
In this work, we demonstrate how to use strong π pulses to generate spin echoes, even when there is no net initial magnetization present before the application of these pulses.

The subgrid scale stress tensor is an important quantity in Large Eddy Simulation (LES), which describes the effect of unresolved turbulent motions on the resolved scales.

In this work, we consider the issue of downlink transmission in multi-user MIMO systems, where each user is equipped with multiple antennas, and the base station has imperfect channel state information (CSI).

We propose a spatially intertwined coding beamforming scheme suitable for both single-user and multi-user scenarios, aimed at improving system performance in the presence of imperfect CSI at the transmitter.
In particular, we first developed an optimal linear precoding scheme based on the minimum mean square error criterion, utilizing the statistical properties of the estimated channel.
Then, we introduce two practical coding schemes that can be effectively implemented using low-density parity-check codes or polar codes.
Finally, numerical results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed solution compared to existing solutions.
The main contributions of this paper include: 1)
Optimal Linear Precoding Scheme: When the number of transmitting antennas approaches infinity, we derive a closed-form expression for the ergodic capacity achieved by the optimal linear precoder.
2) Practical coding design: We design practical coding schemes that can be efficiently implemented, using LDPC codes or polar codes.
3) Numerical Results: We present simulation results to demonstrate the advantages of our proposed solution compared to existing solutions.

The segmentation clock is an oscillatory gene regulatory network that controls the periodic formation of segments in vertebrates, such as vertebrae and ribs.

The segmented clock consists of two interlocked feedback loops with different time scales; one loop involves the Hes1-7 genes (related to Hairy/Enhancer-of-split), which express periodically in each cycle of the other loop, while the other loop involves the Notch-Delta-Stat3-Gata6-8-Hes7 genes.
