1 Introduction  
Broad Absorption Line Quasars (BALQSOs) exhibit blueshifted absorption features in their emission spectra. They account for only 10% to 20% of optically selected quasar samples, but may comprise up to 50% of the total ultraviolet continuum radiation flux absorbed by intervening gas clouds along the line of sight toward distant quasars (Weymann et al., 1991).

In addition to serving as an important probe of the internal physical conditions of gas absorption, BALQSOs also provide information about the properties of the surrounding interstellar medium through the study of relevant metallic line systems (for example, Weymann et al., 1979; Foltz et al., 1986; Turnshek & Savage 1988; Hamann 1998a, b, 1999).

However, despite the undeniable importance of these celestial bodies to cosmological tools, there has been little progress in understanding them since their first discovery over 30 years ago, mainly due to the inherent selection effects in optical surveys (see, for example, Hewett & Foltz 2003).

Recently, several authors have suggested that many BALQSOs may be found among infrared-selected sources, thanks to large-area near-infrared sky surveys, such as the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS) (Cutri et al.).

We present new observations of the central region of the nearby Seyfert galaxy NGC 4258, which show that its nuclear disk is tilted by about 20 degrees relative to the plane of the host galaxy's stellar bulge (see Figure 1).
The distortion has been detected through near-infrared integral field spectroscopy observations obtained at the James Clerk Maxwell Telescope on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

We also reported the detection of a significant rotation in the sub-axis direction of this distorted structure, as well as evidence of reverse rotation within a few hundred seconds of arc in the innermost part of the nucleus.
These results are consistent with previous studies based solely on optical data.

In addition, we found that if gas moves around the supermassive black hole located at the center of the galaxy and is influenced by gravity and magnetic fields, the kinematics of the gas in the outer regions of the nuclear disk can be explained.
This result suggests that the observed distortion may originate from the magnetic shear instability (MRI) present in the accretion disk surrounding the massive black hole.

Finally, we discuss how these findings help us understand the physical mechanism behind the so-called "Baldwin-Peterson effect": the alignment between the spin axis of stars and the angular momentum vector of the material accreting onto the central supermassive black hole.
We present new observations of the distant galaxy cluster RX J1117.4+07431, which was discovered by Voges et al. (1999) in ROSAT All-Sky Survey data.
The cluster is located at a redshift of z = 0.485 ± 0.001, with an estimated mass of M500 = 1.7 × 10^13 h⁻¹M⊙, within a radius of r500 = 2.1 h⁻¹ Mpc.
We used the Suprime-Cam on the Subaru telescope to obtain deep field optical images to study its member galaxies.
In addition, we observed this galaxy cluster with Chandra ACIS-I for about 50 kiloseconds.
Our results are as follows: The color-brightness diagram shows the presence of a red sequence of early-type galaxies, down to our limiting brightness of RAB = 25 mag.
Through photometric redshift analysis, we found that the number density profile of member galaxies within 3 times the virtual radius closely aligns with the predictions of the NFW model.
The temperature map derived from the observations of the Chandra Observatory shows two hot spots near the center of the cluster.
These features may be associated with shock heating caused by merger activities between subgroups or groups.
We present new observations of polarized radio emission from the nearby (7 Mpc) grand design spiral galaxy NGC 6946 using the Very Large Array (VLA) at a frequency of 1.4 GHz.
The data reveals some interesting features that were not found in previous continuous radio studies of the galaxy.
We found that the total intensity distribution is dominated by two bright core components, which are located about 2 kpc apart along an axis perpendicular to the main galactic plane.
There is no evidence of large-scale ordered fields on the scale of kiloparsecs, as previously reported.

The polarization vector shows a distinct pattern of alternating directions in the central region of the Milky Way galaxy, which we interpret as a characteristic of the global magnetic field reversal between two nuclei.

The rotation measurement diagram shows a ring-like structure around each nucleus, where the RM symbol changes, indicating that the magnetic field component in the direction of the line of sight has varied.
This feature may be related to the so-called depolarization rings observed in other galaxies, but it could also be caused by beam smearing effects or intrinsic Faraday dispersion within the source.
The distribution of polarization intensity reveals some extended structures, including a significant southern arm that extends more than 10 kiloparsecs to the southeast.

We propose an improved equation of state (EOS) for the ground state of quantum hard spheres, used to describe dense matter in astrophysics and nuclear physics. This equation is based on the exact solution of the Schrödinger equation with a repulsive delta function potential.
EOS is obtained by numerically solving the corresponding integral equation using the successive iteration method.
We have also obtained analytical expressions for pressure and energy density as functions of particle number density at zero temperature.

We compared our results with those previously computed under various approximations, including the second-order virial expansion, the Carnahan-Starling approximation, and the Pexter-Yevick approximation.
It turns out that our new EOS is very consistent with these previous computational results across a wide range of densities and temperatures.
This specific situation accurately reproduces the low-density limit in which the ideal gas law holds true.
Keywords: Equation of state
We present the collision model results for two spatially resolved debris disks, HD 69830 and AU Mic.
We found that in most of these systems, collisions can effectively produce dust particles with diameters ranging from 1 millimeter to 10 centimeters.

The observed radial distribution can be reproduced by assuming an initial power-law particle size distribution (with an exponent of -3.5, which aligns with theoretical predictions) and allowing it to evolve over millions of years under the influence of mutual collisions.
In addition, we demonstrate how our model reproduces the color gradients observed in the two systems.
Finally, we discussed the possible impact of this work on the formation mechanisms of stars and planets.

The purpose of this study is to explore the role of evaluation in the communication between teachers and students in a Computer-Based Learning Environment (CBLE).
The guiding question of this study is: How does it affect teacher-student interaction?
This study was conducted among two groups of undergraduate students at a large Midwestern university, who were enrolled in a foundational course on educational technology.
Students are required to use a computer-based learning environment (CBLE) called WebQuests to complete three tasks. This environment is designed for students to use individually or collaboratively.

Data collection includes audio recordings of the group discussions, field notes taken by researchers while observing the work of each group, and the written responses of students to the questions posed during their participation in the project.

The analysis shows that assessment plays multiple roles in these interactions, including providing feedback on individual performance, clarifying expectations, establishing fundamental rules, and facilitating reflection.

These findings indicate that when evaluations are conducted frequently enough over a certain period, they can effectively enhance communication between teachers and students, allowing both parties multiple opportunities to respond to each other.
We proposed the first dual field theory that emerges in the new spacetime, which is derived from the unified field theory in higher-dimensional spacetime.
We have demonstrated that this new dual-field theory can be used to describe quantum physics and classical physics with a unified description.
This new dual field theory has several advantages compared to other existing theories, such as string theory/M-theory or loop quantum gravity.
Firstly, it provides a clear mathematical formula to describe all physical phenomena from the microscopic scale to the macroscopic scale.
Secondly, unlike string theory/M-theory or quantum gravity theory, our new dual field theory will not require any dimensions beyond those that have been experimentally observed.
Third, we provide a specific example to demonstrate how our new dual-field theory derives Einstein's general relativity.
Finally, we also derive Maxwell's equations from our new dual field.

These results provide new insights into the physical conditions of the interstellar medium surrounding active galactic nuclei in their early evolutionary stages.

In the past few decades, the detection of carbon monoxide (CO), one of the most abundant molecules in the universe, has been widely used to study the properties of cold neutral atomic and molecular gas in galaxies across cosmic time.
However, CO is difficult to observe directly due to the lack of an electric dipole moment, and its emission is very weak.

In addition, the excitation temperature of CO's lowest rotational energy levels is usually quite low, so the frequencies of these transitions generally fall outside the frequency range that ground-based observatories can access at millimeter wavelengths.

Therefore, our understanding of the physical conditions present in dense regions of galaxies where star formation occurs primarily comes from studies of other molecular gas tracers, including HCN, H2S, CS, CH3OH, H2O, and OH+.
We present new asteroseismic analysis results of the primary component of the binary system Alpha Centauri, based on data obtained from the HARPS spectrograph at the La Silla Observatory in Chile.
We found two independent frequencies, which may be related to the rotational splitting pattern.
The observed frequency patterns are consistent with theoretical predictions, indicating that the inclination angle of this star is between 40° and 60°.

Keywords: Asteroseismology, rotation, binary stars, oscillation, frequency analysis, high-precision radial velocity, Alpha Centauri.

Abstract: We report new results from asteroseismic analysis of the main-sequence F-type star Alpha Centauri A, which forms a close binary system with its cooler companion star, Alpha Centauri B.

Our research utilizes high-precision radial velocity measurement data collected over more than four years with the HARPS instrument installed on the European Southern Observatory’s 3.6-meter telescope at the La Silla Observatory in the Andes Mountains of Chile, in conjunction with photometric observations conducted simultaneously with the CoRoT space mission.

Using standard techniques applied in asteroseismology, we detected several periodic signals in two datasets, including one periodic signal with a period that exactly corresponds to the orbital period of the system.
This discovery confirms the previous suggestion that the pulsation behavior of this star may be influenced by tidal effects caused by a companion star.
Through the addition, our analysis reveals a set of signals corresponding to a period range from approximately 1 day to nearly 2 days.
These signals can be interpreted as resulting from the rotationally split p-mode oscillations excited in the convective envelope of the star.
Their existence provides strong support for the hypothesis that the surface of Alpha Centauri A is formed by magnetic activity driven by generator processes within the convective zone.
We present new rest-frame ultraviolet spectra of four Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs) with redshifts between 5 and 6, obtained using the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph on the Hubble Space Telescope.
These data are used to measure the properties of the interstellar medium in these celestial bodies by fitting models to the observed absorption line profiles.

We found that the metallicity of all four LBGs (Lyman Break Galaxies) is high, ranging from 0.2 times solar metallicity to 1 times solar metallicity, which is consistent with previous results based on optical spectra.
In addition, we detected strong outflows in the three targets, evidenced by the blue-shifted interstellar absorption lines.
These observations suggest that massive stars may have driven galactic-scale winds before reionization was completed.

This paper is part of a series of papers dedicated to studying the electronic structure and physical properties of uranium-based materials.
Here, we present a theoretical study on the magnetic properties of U/Cu and U/Ag interfaces.

We use spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the exchange interaction along the [001] direction at different distances under the local density approximation (LDA) and the generalized gradient approximation (GGA).

Statistical mechanics on networks is an emerging field that has received widespread attention in recent years, especially after the discovery of scale-free and small-world characteristics in many real-world systems, such as social networks, biological networks, and technological networks.
In this presentation, I will introduce some statistical mechanics results regarding random graphs with arbitrary degree distributions.
The main focus will be on the phase transitions related to the emergence/disappearance of giant connected components (GCC) in these diagrams.
We demonstrate how to use generating function techniques to accurately compute the probability distribution function of the size of GCC (Giant Connected Component).
This allows us to analytically study the effects of various parameters (such as average connectivity, clustering coefficient, node degree, etc.) on the formation of GCCs.

Introduction  
Molecular clouds play an important role in star formation (SF) because they provide the materials necessary for the formation of stars.
However, it is still unclear what physical mechanisms drive star formation within molecular clouds.
A possible mechanism involves supersonic turbulence driven by supernova explosions or stellar winds (Mac Low & Klessen 2004).

Another possibility is that a large-scale gravitational collapse could trigger local fragmentation, leading to the formation of dense cores that subsequently evolve into protostars (Larson 1978; Bonnell et al., 1997).
Some scholars suggest that during different stages of molecular cloud evolution, two scenarios may coexist (Krumholz 2014).
Recent observational studies have shown that many young massive stars are associated with the filamentary structures observed in infrared dust emission maps (André et al. 2010).

By analyzing the correspondence between Einstein and Max Born (1882-1970), this work examines the relationship between Einstein's contributions to physics, his personal life, and the cultural environment of the time.
These letters reveal that Einstein was not only interested in science, but also had a passion for literature, music, drama, and other cultural forms.
In particular, they showed how he began to appreciate modernist artists such as Wassily Kandinsky, Paul Klee, and Pablo Picasso.
They also provide insights into Einstein's attitude towards society as a whole during this period.

We proposed an improved calculation result to discuss the properties of nuclear matter and the single-particle energy in spherical nuclei, based on covariant density functional theory that includes tensor terms.

We proposed an algorithm for solving the graph isomorphism problem (GIP) based on quantum random walks and Grover's search algorithm.
The proposed method is inspired by classic algorithms that use random walks, but it employs the Grover operator instead of the Hadamard matrix to speed up the process.
We demonstrated how this new technology can solve the GIP problem with a higher probability when the number of vertices in the two graphs is equal or differs by at most one unit.
Finally, we will compare our results with other recent methods.

In recent years, more and more people have become interested in developing efficient solutions to address problems related to computational complexity theory, such as the Graph Isomorphism Problem (GIP).
The question is to determine whether the given two graphs are isomorphic, that is, whether they have the same structure regardless of their labels.
The classic method for solving GIP usually relies on random walk techniques combined with some heuristic algorithms.
However, these methods require exponential time in the worst case.
On the other hand, quantum algorithms provide polynomial time solutions for many NP-complete problems, including GIP.
These algorithms utilize the principle of superposition, allowing them to simultaneously explore all possible states.
For example, the Shor algorithm solves integer factorization in polynomial time, while Grover's search finds any item in a database in square root time.

We demonstrated that both of these models can be embedded into the compactification of 5D theory on an orbifold.

In addition, we demonstrate how these templates play a role in parameter estimation studies using simulated datasets.
Finally, we discussed possible improvements to our work.

We used the Submillimeter Array (SMA) on Mauna Kea in Hawaii to conduct high-resolution millimeter-wave observations at 345 GHz and 1.3 mm to study the distribution of molecular gas along the line of sight to the gravitationally lensed radio source B0218+357.
The lensing galaxy is located between the two images A and C, which are separated by 2.7 arc seconds.
We detected three compact continuous sources associated with each image component.
Through stacking, we discovered several faint emission lines, including CO(3-2), 13CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), CS(5-4), and SiO(8-7).
Based on these results, we conclude that the total flux density consists of four components: one for each image, plus an additional component due to the lensing galaxy.

Asteroid 144898 was discovered on September 24, 2004, by the Catalina Sky Survey. It has a brightness of 18.7 and is classified as a potentially hazardous asteroid due to its larger size.
The orbit was determined through astronomical measurements conducted using the 1-meter telescope at the U.S. Naval Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona, from October 2005 to March 2007.
The data indicates that the object will not have an impact on Earth in the next 100 years, but it could be a good candidate for future space missions.

We studied the decoherence dynamics of an open quantum system, which consists of two-level atoms coupling with a single mode cavity field, and considered the effects of dissipation and driving fields.

The coupling of the atom-cavity is treated within the framework of the Jaynes-Cummings model, while the dissipative effects are described by the master equation for the reduced density matrix of the system.
We indicate that when the decay rates of all atomic energy levels are equal, the steady-state solution to this problem can be obtained through analytical methods.

Specifically, we find that the steady-state entanglement between the atom and the field subsystems depends on both the strength of the external driving field and the number of excited states involved in the process.
Finally, we discussed how our results can be used to explain recent experimental observations regarding the generation of non-classical light through the spontaneous emission process.

We present new Chandra observations of the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) at the center of Abell 3395 (z=0.084).
BCG is surrounded by an extended halo with a temperature range of 1 keV to 5 keV.
We found that due to interactions with other galaxies in the core of the star cluster, this hot gas has displaced from its original position around the central galaxy.
Through addition, we detected two radio sources associated with BCG, which may be jets or bow shocks from an active galactic nucleus.
Finally, we identified several regions where the cold gas may have condensed from the surrounding hot plasma.
The results indicate that the BCG in Abell 3395 is significantly interacting with its environment.
This work was supported by NASA contract NAS8-39073 issued through JPL/Caltech.

We studied the electric excitation of nonlinear waves under voltage bias in a two-dimensional channel, which is composed of two parallel metal plates separated by a dielectric layer.
We demonstrated that different types of nonlinear waves can be excited based on the parameters of the system (the thickness of the medium layer and the density of electrons).
In particular, we found that for certain values of these parameters, there exist solitary wave solutions analogous to those found early in one-dimensional systems.

The existence of this solitary wave has been experimentally verified through time-resolved reflectance measurements conducted at room temperature on GaAs/AlGaAs quantum well samples grown by molecular beam epitaxy.
These experiments reveal that bright solitary waves propagate in a direction perpendicular to the applied electric field.
Their propagation speeds are very consistent with the theoretical predictions from numerical simulations based on the underlying equations.

The results presented here may have important applications in semiconductor devices, and it has recently been demonstrated that the generation of solitary waves can lead to improved performance characteristics.
We present new spectral observations of two globular clusters in the nearby galaxy NGC 5128 (also known as Centaurus A).
The GCs are located at a predicted distance of approximately 3 kiloparsecs to 10 kiloparsecs from the center of this elliptical galaxy.
We obtained high-resolution spectra using Gemini/GMOS-S during three different nights in 2013-2014.
These data enable us to measure the radial velocities of the two globular clusters more accurately, with a precision better than 1 kilometer per second.
In addition, we also obtained line-of-sight velocity dispersion using the same GMOS-S data.
For a star cluster, we found that its system velocity is very consistent with the previous measurements by other authors.
However, there are significant differences between our measurements of the second cluster and the previously published values.
This difference may be due to contamination from a potential stellar population, or it may be incorrectly classified as a globular cluster (GC).

We present the results of analyzing the globular cluster (GC) systems of four massive elliptical galaxies (NGC 4889, NGC 4636, NGC 5846, and NGC 6166), using deep imaging data obtained from the Wide Field Channel of the Advanced Camera for Surveys on the Hubble Space Telescope.

We found that these gravitationally condensed systems are multimodal; they are composed of at least two subgroups that exhibit significant differences in color distribution and spatial distribution within each galaxy.
The center concentration of the blue subgroup is higher than that of the red subgroup, while outside the central area, the radial distribution characteristics of both are similar.
These findings suggest that the formation histories of these two subgroups may be different.

Specifically, we propose that the blue subpopulation forms during significant merger processes between gas-rich disk galaxies, while the red subpopulation is assembled through minor mergers with dwarf galaxies or low-mass elliptical galaxies and/or accretion events.

The Kuranov drag effect refers to the phenomenon in which a charge carrier transfers energy to another charge carrier by exchanging virtual phonons, resulting in a current in the second carrier that flows in the opposite direction to its own motion.

We found that for small spacings (less than 10 nanometers), there is a significant deviation compared to the predictions made by standard theories developed for bulk materials.
These deviations are caused by the existence of vanishing modes that are strongly coupled with low-energy carriers.

The results provided here offer useful information on how to design devices such as transistors or thermoelectric generators using graphene layers.

It is composed of carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal lattice structure and behaves like a two-dimensional electron gas after doping [2].
One interesting property of graphene is the so-called Coulomb drag effect.
The electrons in the second layer generate current by moving in the first layer, even though they do not directly interact with each other.
The reason for this effect is due to the interaction between two charge carriers exchanging virtual phonons through the medium. [5]
Therefore, the current density of the second carrier depends on the velocity of the first carrier.

One reason for this difficulty is the wide range of length scales involved in turbulence.
Due to the fact that the large vortices contain most of the kinetic energy, they only occupy a small portion of the total volume.
On the other hand, the small vortices almost fill all the space, but their contribution to the overall kinetic energy is minimal.
Therefore, if one wants to accurately resolve all relevant flow structures, a very fine mesh is required, which will result in extremely high computational costs.
To address this issue, the so-called Large Eddy Simulation (LES) has been developed over the past two decades [1, 2].

These technologies aim to address large-scale movements that account for most of the momentum, while simulating the effects of unresolved small-scale fluctuations through appropriate closure relationships.

Although Large Eddy Simulation (LES) has been successfully applied to various engineering problems [3–5], it also has some drawbacks, such as the lack of generality in the subgrid-scale models used [6].
In recent years, several new methods similar to LES have emerged.

We present the first measurement of the mass function of supermassive black holes (SMBH) in early-type (elliptical/S0, Sa-Sb) and late-type (Scd-Sm) galaxies using data from the Millennium Galaxy Catalog (MGC).
We use two different methods to measure the mass of supermassive black holes—stellar velocity dispersion measurements and the luminosity calibration relation of globular clusters.
Our results indicate that there are no significant differences in the supermassive black hole (SMBH) mass functions of these galaxy types when z < 0.1.
However, we found evidence of evolution with redshift, indicating that the number density of massive supermassive black holes decreases more rapidly than that of smaller mass black holes.
This indicates that the supermassive black holes with the maximum mass may have grown through accretion during the epoch of the universe, rather than through merging events.
These findings may impose significant constraints on models of supermassive black hole (SMBH) growth and active galactic nucleus (AGN) feedback.

The Neutrino Factory and Muon Collider Collaboration (NFMCC), in cooperation with other European laboratories, has proposed an innovative concept to use a large liquid argon imaging detector in future neutrino factory or muon collider experiments at CERN.
The proposed project aims to utilize state-of-the-art technology to construct a very large modular liquid argon time projection chamber (LArTPC).

This will enable us to take advantage of the unique features offered by this type of detector, such as excellent particle identification capabilities, high spatial resolution, good time resolution, a sealed detection volume, and the ability to operate in strong magnetic fields, all of which are fundamental requirements for the precise measurement of neutrino oscillation parameters.

We have detected for the first time the secondary cosmic microwave background radiation polarization caused by Faraday rotation (FR) in galaxy clusters, using data obtained from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope polarimeter (ACTPol).
We detected polarization radiation induced by FR at multipole numbers = 100-1000 at angular scales in two galaxy clusters: ACT-CL J0102-4915 and ACT-CL J0546-5345.
The observed signals are consistent with the theoretical predictions based on numerical simulations of the magnetized stellar cluster atmosphere.

This measurement provides an important test for our understanding of the magnetic fields in galaxy clusters and their impact on cosmological observables, such as cosmic microwave background radiation temperature anisotropy and E-mode polarization.
In addition, we report the upper limits of the FR-induced polarized radiation from other galaxy clusters that could not be detected separately due to low signal-to-noise ratio or limited survey area.
These results will be very useful for future research on the impact of FR on the CMB polarization maps produced by upcoming experiments, such as the Planck satellite and the Simons Observatory.
We present the results of the rotating condensate in an optical trap calculated using the distorted HFB method and Skyrmion interactions.

We found that, unlike the predictions of mean field theory, there is no phase transition between the superfluid state and the normal state. However, we observed that as the angular velocity increases, the density of the condensate continues to decrease.
The reduction rate largely depends on the strength of the pairing force.
This result can be explained by the rotation that disperses the Cooper pairs into single particles that are no longer bound together.

In addition to this effect, we also observed another interesting phenomenon: at certain specific angular velocities, the density of the condensed state is greater than its value when there is no rotation.

Finally, we compare our results with those obtained by other authors using different methods, such as time-dependent GP equations or Bogoliubov-de Gennes equations.

We are considering the problem of finding the shortest path between two nodes in an undirected graph, where the edge weights are non-negative, and the constraint is that no node can be visited more than once along the path.
We show how to solve this problem by simplifying it to a minimum cost flow problem on a directed acyclic network, and then applying standard techniques to solve these problems.
The running time is O(n³ log n), where n represents the number of vertices in the input graph.
This result improves on the algorithm that was previously known only under special circumstances (for example, when all edge weights are unit weights).
Keywords: shortest path, minimum cost flow, directed graph, undirected graph, converging path, constraints, flow network, computational complexity theory.
1 Introduction

In many applications, it is necessary to find the shortest path between two given nodes s and t in an undirected weighted graph G = (V, E), while not allowing any vertex to appear more than once in the path.
For example, if we want to calculate the distance between two cities using a road map, we may not allow using the same city as the starting point after visiting another city.
In other words, we do not want to use the same stretch of road repeatedly, even though there may be several different ways to reach a destination.
Another application appears in computational biology, where people aim to find a gene sequence that minimizes total length while avoiding certain DNA regions.

The third application appears in the field of computer vision, where people seek to minimize the total length of a path through a set of images, while ensuring that each image appears at most once in the path.
Finally, our results also apply to the problem of calculating the diameter of connected undirected graphs.
The first algorithm for calculating the shortest path that satisfies these constraints was proposed by Hassin and Rubinov.
[HR91] shows how to reduce problems with minimal cost flow.

We analyzed the energy and brightness dependence of the frequencies of two types of quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) observed in the power density spectrum of accreting black holes: low-frequency QPOs (LFQPOs; 0.1-10 Hz), which are believed to be related to the global properties of the flow near the central object, and high-frequency QPOs (HFQPOs; 10-100 Hz).

We report on the radio spectral evolution during the solar flare observed by RHESSI on February 18, 2002, which is one of the most energetic impulsive solar flares recorded to date, with high-energy electrons reaching up to about 100 MeV.
The flare started around 17:45 Coordinated Universal Time and is classified as a GOES M5.7 event, with its peak occurring around 18:10.
It shows two peaks in the hard X-ray light curve (HXR); the first peak lasted only 3 minutes, while the second peak lasted for more than 10 minutes.
We found that the evolution of the radio spectrum has three distinct stages: the pre-flare stage, the impact stage, and the decay stage.
In addition, we also found a significant correlation between the radio radiation and the flux of high-energy X-rays as well as the flux density of microwaves.
During the impulsive phase, the radio radiation increases rapidly, and then slowly declines after the impulsive phase ends.

This book is written for students who have completed the first year of control theory courses, aiming to provide them with a deeper understanding of discrete-time systems, digital controllers, and computer-based control technology.

This text covers topics such as state space representation, stability analysis, optimal control design, robustness issues, model predictive control (MPC), and fuzzy logic-based control, with a focus on practical applications.
It also includes several examples to illustrate the key concepts discussed in each chapter.
This textbook comprehensively covers the fundamental principles of various aspects of modern control engineering.

The exercises at the end of each chapter help readers reinforce their understanding of the material presented earlier.

This book is suitable for graduate students pursuing advanced courses in control theory, as well as scholars engaged in research in this field.

In recent years, an increasing number of researchers have focused on studying the relationship between the properties of galaxies (such as star formation rates (SFRs), stellar mass, morphology, etc.) and the dark matter halos in which they reside.
The motivation behind this is that understanding this connection will help us understand how galaxies evolve over cosmic time.
For example, using observational data from galaxy clustering statistics to constrain galaxy formation and evolution models may be feasible.
However, these measurements can only provide statistical information about the average characteristics of a large number of galaxies.
To obtain more detailed information about individual objects, we need to study them separately.
One way to achieve this goal is through direct imaging technologies such as the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).
Another method involves measuring the flux emitted by different types of atoms using spectral methods.

These include the optical/ultraviolet light produced by ionized atoms, the infrared radiation generated by warm dust particles heated by young stars, the radio continuum radiation resulting from synchrotron processes related to supernova remnants, the free-free radiation from HII regions surrounding hot massive stars, and finally, the most important tracer - the 21-centimeter hyperfine transition of neutral hydrogen (HI).
HI tracks all the cold neutral gas in the interstellar medium (ISM), including molecular clouds and diffuse atomic gas.
It also provides valuable kinematic information about the dynamics of the galactic disk.
Therefore, hydrogen atoms (HI) play a crucial role in our understanding of many physical phenomena related to galaxy formation and evolution.

Planets form from dust particles through a coagulation process (Safronov 1969; Wetherill & Stewart 1989), followed by an uncontrolled aggregation of these growing bodies (Lissauer 1987).
This process led to the formation of planetary particles, whose mass ranges from \(10^{-6}\) M⊕ to several Earth masses.

These celestial bodies, if they accrete enough material in a short period of time, can further develop into larger planetary embryos, and may even directly form gas giants like Jupiter and Saturn (Pollack et al. 1996).
Once formed, these massive planets can carve out gaps in the surrounding stellar disk due to the tidal torques exerted by their planetary gravity (Lin and Papaloizou 1986).
Therefore, the remaining material inside the gap will be quickly removed due to the viscosity effect, leading to rapid inward Type II migration of the planet (Ward 1997; Tanaka et al., 2002).

The distribution of observed exoplanets shows a variety of orbital configurations, ranging from circular orbits around sun-like stars to highly eccentric orbits around low-mass stars (see, for example, Marcy et al. (2005), Udry and Santos (2007), Winn et al. (2010), and Johnson et al. (2011), along with the references therein).

We proposed an efficient numerical scheme to address the nonlinear dynamics of semiconductor microcavity lasers with arbitrary pump profiles and cavity losses, which is based on a combination of two different truncation schemes.

The first method is to reduce the number of equations by eliminating those that are irrelevant at any given moment; this allows us to obtain accurate results even when only a few modes contribute significantly to the total emission spectrum.
The second one is used to eliminate the rapid oscillation terms that arise due to the presence of multiple longitudinal modes within each transverse mode family.
We demonstrated how these two technologies combine into a single algorithm, which we call "Dynamic Control Truncation" (DCT).
Finally, we demonstrated the accuracy and efficiency of our method by comparing it with other existing methods.
Specifically, we consider three different types of pumping characteristics: constant pumping, periodic pumping, and random pulse pumping.

The Internet Archive (IA) is an open-access digital library that aims to collect, preserve, and provide access to records of web culture.
IA has been collecting data since 1996, regularly using the Wayback Machine service to crawl the internet and archive snapshots of websites.
Through this work, we propose a novel method to efficiently store a large number of web pages by leveraging the inherent redundancy of archived web pages.

We propose a new storage model called WARCStore, which is based on the concept of inverted files. Each page is represented as a set of records that contain its content as well as pointers to other relevant pages stored in the same file system.
This enables us to store multiple copies of the same page in different locations while still maintaining fast random read and write performance.
Our experiments show that when storing millions of archived web pages, our proposed solution outperforms existing solutions, such as B-tree indexes or LSM trees.
SDSS J233325 is an unusual cataclysmic variable star (CV), with a magnetic white dwarf as its primary star, and has been classified as an intermediate polar star (IP).
The system shows strong X-ray radiation, but there is no archival data for optical counterparts.
We used the Liverpool telescope to obtain new photometric observations, aiming to search for the periodic modulation expected if the source is indeed an interactive variable star (IP).
No significant periodicity was found over a wide period range from 0.01 seconds to 10 hours.
However, we have indeed found evidence of two quasi-periodic oscillations with frequencies of approximately 0.2 Hz and 0.4 Hz.
These are similar to those seen earlier in other variable stars that contain magnetic white dwarfs.
In addition, it seems that there are also some structures over a longer time scale.
This may represent additional low-frequency QPOs or possible orbital changes.
If confirmed through further observations, this will provide important constraints for theoretical models regarding accretion onto magnetized white dwarfs.

We present the results of an optical spectral follow-up observation campaign targeted at a group of X-ray selected active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with extreme characteristics. This sample was observed in the first year (2000) of the XMM-Newton Serendipitous Source Catalog (XMM-SSC).
The main goal is to study their properties and physical characteristics through multi-band observations.
We have obtained spectra for about half of the sample using several telescopes from different observatories around the world.

The X-ray survey provides a large sample of active galactic nuclei (AGN), which can be statistically studied over a wide range of luminosities, redshifts, and other parameters.

To select a complete sample of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) with extreme properties, we applied very strict selection criteria based on the source count rates and photon indices measured in the 0.5-2 keV band.

Our final sample contains 56 sources, including four known quasars.

We reported the valley-related optoelectronic properties in monolayer WSe2, a semiconductor with strong spin-orbit coupling and a large exciton binding energy, which exhibits broken inversion symmetry.
We demonstrate that circularly polarized light can control the valley polarization of optically excited carriers through optical pumping at room temperature.
Under weak excitation conditions, it was found that the valley polarization lifetime for both electrons and holes is approximately 1 nanosecond.
This work opens up new opportunities for the exploration of novel valleytronic devices based on two-dimensional materials.
"Graphene electronics" has been proposed as a promising method for achieving breakthroughs beyond traditional silicon technology based on spintronics.

Monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) are an emerging class of two-dimensional semiconductors, characterized by their unique layered structure and broken inversion symmetry.
They have attracted widespread attention because they exhibit significant electronic, mechanical, thermal, and optical properties.
Additionally, TMDCs have high carrier mobility, making them ideal candidate materials for future valleytronic applications.
Here, we present the valley-dependent optoelectronic properties in monolayer WSe2 through time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy.
By exciting WSe2 with circularly polarized light, we observed that the valley polarization lifetime of photoexcited carriers is approximately 1 nanosecond for both electrons and holes.
Our results provide direct evidence for the valley-dependent optoelectronic processes in this material system.

We conducted an analysis of N-body simulations to understand how evaporation affects the mass function (MF) of globular clusters (GCs).

We found that, consistent with previous studies, evaporation leads to star clusters preferentially losing stars in the low-mass region, thereby making the slope of the mass function steeper towards lower masses.

However, we show that this effect is counterbalanced by two competing processes: dynamic friction more effectively removes a large number of massive stars rather than lower-mass stars; and core collapse driven by relaxation, which increases the central density of the cluster, making it more difficult for a large number of stars to escape.
The final results largely depend on the initial cluster concentration, but generally lead to a shallower slope compared to the slopes observed in real star clusters.
This indicates that other processes are needed to explain the shape of the observed mass distribution.
In particular, our results indicate that original binary systems may be the reason for the formation of the high-quality power-law tails observed in many globular clusters.

Introduction: In recent years, there have been many attempts to construct solutions to the Einstein field equations corresponding to rotating black holes [1] - [4].

A particularly interesting class of solutions discovered by Bañados, Teitelboim, and Zanelli (BTZ) demonstrates how to obtain static black hole solutions in three-dimensional anti-de Sitter spacetime.

The most important feature of these solutions is their asymptotic behavior; the event horizon of the black holes they describe is completely determined by global quantities such as total energy or charge.
However, although these solutions are very useful for studying quantum gravity phenomena [7, 8], they do not provide any information about the local properties of spacetime near the horizon [9].
Therefore, it seems necessary to attempt to extend them into a more complex geometry that includes additional parameters characterizing the internal structure of black holes. [10]
One way to do this is to consider the higher-dimensional extension of the BTZ solution [11].
Another possibility is to perform a dual transformation on the known solution [12].

For example, if we start from the Schwarzschild solution expressed in spherical coordinates and then perform an appropriate coordinate transformation, we will obtain another solution expressed in oblate spheroidal coordinates [13].

We compared the performance of two different methods for simulating nonequilibrium dynamics in polymer systems, namely the dissipative particle dynamics (DPD) using the Nosé-Hoover or Langevin thermostat.
We indicate that both DPD schemes can reproduce qualitatively similar results when compared to each other and in comparison with the results of stretching experiments of single DNA molecules.
However, we found that there is a significant difference in quantity between the two methods, which can be attributed to the fundamentally different motion equations they use.
In particular, we demonstrate how these differences affect the relaxation behavior after an external force is applied to the end of the chain.
Finally, we discuss possible methods to overcome some shortcomings of the current implementation approach.

The Markus-Lushnikov process is a continuous-time analogue of the discrete-time Lévy walk model proposed by Montrol and Weiss in 1965, which is used to describe the behavior of diffusion-limited aggregation (DLA) on fractal surfaces.

The DLA (Diffusion Limited Aggregation) growth mechanism has been observed experimentally for many years, but it is only recently that attempts have been made to mathematically model it using stochastic processes, such as the Marcus-Lushnikov process.
In this article, we consider two issues related to the Marcus-Lushnikov model:

First, we prove that the jump distribution of the underlying Lévy process satisfies certain integrability conditions, and then the corresponding Marcus-Lushnikov process weakly converges to a Brownian motion with drift. Secondly, we demonstrate how the Marcus-Lushnikov model is used to approximate the solution of Smoluchowski's coalescence-fragmentation equation, which describes the evolution of particle size distribution in chemical reactions involving particle clusters.
We also discussed some connections with the Marcus-Lushnikov and Flory polymer models.

We reported on the impedance spectroscopy study conducted on BiFeO3 (BFO) and BaTiO3 (BT) films of varying thicknesses grown on single-crystal SrTiO3 substrates using pulsed laser deposition technology.

We propose an evolutionary model that describes the emergence of genes, species, and their interactions through physical principles.
The model is based on the concept of self-assembly, a process that occurs during the formation of biomacromolecules such as proteins or nucleic acids.
We demonstrated how this process leads to the spontaneous emergence of the functional units we call "gene families."
The gene family is defined by common sequence patterns and can be regarded as the building blocks of more complex organisms.
In our approach, these building blocks evolve into new species through mutation and selection processes.
Species interact with each other through enzyme-mediated chemical reactions.
These interactions promote the formation of metabolic networks, and their structure reflects the fundamental network topology of the interacting species.

Finally, we demonstrate how the proposed model reproduces several important features observed in real-world systems, including preferential attachment, scale-free distribution, and small-world properties.
Our research results indicate that the fundamental mechanisms driving the evolution of life may have been established right at the beginning of life.

PoGOLite is an experiment designed to measure the degree and angle of linear polarization of photons in the energy range of 100 MeV to 1 GeV, emitted by astrophysical sources such as pulsars or active galactic nuclei (AGN).

The vapor pressure, solubility in water, and interfacial tension between oil and water are important parameters for understanding the behavior of crude oil during production or pipeline transportation.
In this study, we used alcohol monolayers on aqueous subphases as a model system to simulate the hydrocarbon chains present in crude oil and investigated these properties.
The results indicate that the vapor pressure of alcohol compounds increases with chain length up to C8, but decreases beyond C10.
This is explained by considering the competition between two opposing effects: on one hand, increasing the chain length leads to a higher molecular volume, which is beneficial for evaporation.
On the other hand, longer chains can lead to stronger van der Waals interactions in the liquid phase, thereby reducing the vapor pressure.
We found that the solubility of alcohols is similar to the observed trend in vapor pressure.
However, compared to the corresponding differences in vapor pressure, the differences in solubility between different chain lengths become smaller.
Finally, our measurement results indicate that the interfacial tension between the alkanol layer and the underlying water decreases monotonically with increasing chain length.

We presented numerical simulations to study the formation, evolution, and collapse of quiet cloud cores caused by dynamic compression in turbulent molecular clouds.
We found that these cloud cores are formed by shock compression at the intersections of shock waves driven by supersonic turbulence.
The mass range of the cloud core is between 0.1 M⊙ and 1 M⊙, with a typical size of about 1000 AU.

The internal velocity of these cloud cores is relatively low (< 2 km s^-1), but during their lifecycle, they can be accelerated to 10 km s^-1 due to gravitational interactions with other dense clumps within the same cloud.
Most of them evolve in a quasi-static manner over several free-fall time scales, and then dynamically collapse on a timescale of one to ten free-fall times.
Our results indicate that these cloud cores may be an important source of protostars in star formation regions.
Keywords: turbulence, star formation

We study the dynamics of the asymmetric exclusion process of two types of particles on a circular structure, where particles can jump to the adjacent sites on the right or left and are affected by hard-core exclusion.
We prove that for any initial condition, there exists a unique steady state characterized by a density distribution that depends solely on the distance between positions.
Specifically, we found that this profile rapidly exhibits exponential decay as it moves away from the origin.

This result implies that the system exhibits dynamic screening, meaning that even if its underlying microscopic model lacks translational invariance, correlations will still exhibit rapid exponential decay at large distances.
The proof relies on a combination of techniques from probability theory (especially martingale methods) and functional analysis.
Our results are applicable to finite systems and infinite lattices.
I. Introduction In recent years, increasing attention has been focused on the study of non-equilibrium steady states driven by granular gases [1].

These models describe systems of interacting particles that evolve according to random rules. Although they cannot satisfy detailed balance on a global scale [2], they still exhibit interesting macroscopic behavior [3].
This type of model includes the so-called exclusion process [4], which describes the movement of particles along a regular lattice under mutually exclusive constraints [5].
For example, consider a chain composed of L sites, where the sites are labeled with integers 1, 2, ..., L, and each site is either occupied by a particle or is empty.
Particles can jump to adjacent positions on the right or left as long as the position is empty.
If all jumps occur independently, then the resulting Markov process satisfies detailed balance relative to some product measure.

We present the results of direct cosmological fluid dynamics simulations, tracking the formation of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) in galaxy nuclei, their subsequent evolution during the merger process with other SMBHs, and the relevant feedback on galaxy properties.

This is one of the most sensitive fields for detecting extragalactic sources, with a wavelength range of 65 to 90 microns.

By fitting the power spectral density (PSD) to a single power-law model, we obtained the best-fit slopes of -2.1 ± 0.3 at 65 microns and -1.9 ± 0.4 at 90 microns.
These slopes are consistent with the clustering characteristics expected for infrared galaxies.

The origin and evolution of the cosmic magnetic field is one of the most important unsolved problems in astrophysics, closely related to many other fundamental issues such as star formation, galaxy formation, and structure formation.
In this speech, I will review our recent work on simulating the primordial magnetic field, involving different physical processes.
The first part focuses on the seed magnetic field generated by quantum fluctuations during the inflationary period.
We indicate that these seeds can be significantly amplified after reheating, which is caused by magnetohydrodynamic turbulence driven by the decaying expansion field disturbances.
Then we discuss how these seeds evolve into large-scale coherent magnetic fields through various mechanisms, including inverse cascading, generator action, and turbulent pumping.
Finally, we propose some possible observational signatures for future detection.
This speech was delivered at the International Conference on Computing and Theory (ICCT) held in Beijing, China, from September 24 to 27, 2014.

We study the efficiency of relativistic shock waves in accelerating cosmic rays (CR) through Monte Carlo simulations and analytical calculations.
We found that for strong shocks with Mach numbers ranging from 10 to 100, only about 1% of cosmic rays can be accelerated to ultra-high energy (UHE).
This is because most particles are scattered back upstream before they can gain enough energy to cross the shock front again.
The low efficiency of UHE particle production leads to a limit on the maximum proton energy and the total luminosity of cosmic rays produced by such oscillations.
Our results indicate that the observed flux of ultra-high-energy protons cannot be solely explained by the diffusion shock acceleration mechanism operating in cosmic shocks.
However, our findings do not rule out other recently proposed mechanisms to explain the origin of ultra-high-energy cosmic rays.
Keywords: cosmic ray acceleration, diffusion shock acceleration, relativistic shock wave
